sections.heading: 1.1. The Changing Landscape for the Energy and Chemistry Transition
sections.text:
The ongoing energy transition to a more sustainable and lowcarbon future[1–3] pushes the development of advanced materials for energy and catalysis.[4–12] 2D or layered materials are interesting in this regard for their peculiar transient properties
2D oxide nanomaterials constitute a broad range of materials, with a wide array of current and potential applications, particularly in the fields of energy storage and catalysis for sustainable energy production. Despite the many similarities in structure, composition, and synthetic methods and uses, the current literature on layered oxides is diverse and disconnected. A number of reviews can be found in the literature, but they are mostly focused on one of the particular subclasses of 2D oxides. This review attempts to bridge the knowledge gap between individual layered oxide types by summarizing recent developments in all important 2D oxide systems including supported ultrathin oxide films, layered clays and double hydroxides, layered perov skites, and novel 2Dzeolitebased materials. Particular attention is paid to the underlying similarities and differences between the various materials, and the subsequent challenges faced by each research community. The potential of layered oxides toward future applications is critically evaluated, especially in the areas of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, biomass conversion, and fine chemical synthesis. Attention is also paid to corresponding novel 3D mate rials that can be obtained via sophisticated engineering of 2D oxides.

Catalysis is one of the most important sectors for the energy transition and the development of new solutions for a sustainable and low-carbon society.[13–16] Over 90% of currently applied industrial processes for chemical production and refinery use catalysis in one or more process steps.[17] In addition, catalysis plays a crucial role in many technologies for pollution abatement, from both mobile and fixed sources. While most of the catalysts in use are well established, there is a great scope for the development of novel catalytic materials, particularly to address the new requirements from emerging areas such as: i) electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and plasma catalysis for the direct utilization of renewable energy sources; ii) catalytic processes for the use of biomass and other carbon sources (particularly CO2); and iii) use of fossil raw materials as alternatives to oil, such as methane or coal.[13]
Implementation of the transition to low-carbon chemistry and renewable energy sources[2] requires a radical transformation in the way in which chemical and refinery processes are designed. The direct use of renewable energy sources other than heat (derived from fossil raw materials) requires wholesale changes to the core elements of the process, from catalyst to reactor design. While photocatalyst and electrocatalyst have been known for many years, their use in chemical industrial processes has been quite limited up to now and it is thus necessary to develop new solutions and approaches to overcome the limits of productivity and in some cases, stability. Consequently, passing from the conventional “thermal-type” catalytic processes to new “electron-driven” or “photodriven” catalytic processes requires the development of new catalytic materials, electrodes, and devices/reactors. Even for some of the areas that are satisfied by more traditional type of catalysts, such as the use of alternative C-sources for petrochemistry and refineries (largely based on oil), there is the demand for new and innovative types of catalysts.[18]

sections.heading: 1.2. 2D Materials
sections.text:
2D materials (often referred to as thin films) are defined here as single or few-layer nanosheets that have an aspect ratio

(ratio between the in-plane a–b-axes and the perpendicular caxis) greater than about 100. Layered materials, with structures consisting of stacked nanosheets, which may be delaminated due to relatively weak interlayer forces, are a valuable option to develop new materials with controlled accessibility to the active sites and inner surface, and high surface areas.[19–26] These nanomaterials possess distinct properties from corresponding bulk-type materials, which can be exploited to obtain, for example, enhanced electrocatalytic and photocatalytic properties. This allows the development of highly selective and active catalysts, for example, for the production of H2 or the conversion of CO2 into value-added molecules and fuels.[4] 2D nanosheets may be further manipulated to create different nanostructures, for example via self-assembly,[27,28] creating a large range of exciting possibilities. There are various examples showing that exfoliation increases the activity, long-term stability, and especially the selectivity. An example of emerging extraordinary 0D materials[29] is quantum dots. These materials are synthesized in such a way that the lateral growth is suppressed, leading to small sheets with pronounced edge effects.
As a result of the wide range of 2D systems available and the flexibility of properties that may be expected from them, research in the field of 2D materials is growing fast in many application areas, including materials for energy, such as nanophotonic,[30] optoelectronics,[31,32] batteries,[33] gas sensors,[34] ferroelectric- gated 2D- material- based electron devices,[35] and materials with enhanced light–matter interactions.[36] There are many common aspects related to the control of the nanostructure in these advanced applications, which motivate the converging development of materials for catalytic and energy applications.[37,38]
Various classes of 2D nanomaterials have been reported in the literature, with the state of the art for energy applications recently reviewed by Tan et al.[39] They include graphene, hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), metal phosphorus trichalcogenides, layered double hydroxides (LDHs), metal oxides and 2D zeolites, transition metal oxyhalides, metal halides, perovskites and niobates, silicates and hydroxides (clays), metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent−organic frameworks (COFs), and other systems.
From the point of view of catalysis, and limiting ourselves to oxide type materials, the most important classes of materials are clays and LDHs, pillared clays, perovskites and 2D zeolites. These materials will make up the core of discussion in this review.

sections.heading: 1.3. Applications of 2D Oxides
sections.text:
In the previous section, the broad classes of current 2D oxide nanomaterials were introduced in the context of energy and catalysis. We now select several important fields in which layered oxide nanomaterials have proven themselves valuable and give relevant examples from the literature. This list is by no means exhaustive, and discussion in greater depth is given in Sections 2 and 3.

The following important concepts and applications of 2D oxides are emerging:[26,40–51] i) H2 production and biorefinery, ii) photocatalysts for water splitting and CO2 reduction, iii) energy storage and conversion, iv) multifunctional catalysts for cascade reactions, v) environmental applications, vi) 2D zeolites for fine chemistry, vii) encapsulation with 2D oxides, and viii) development of new classes of material.

sections.heading: 1.3.1. H2 Production
sections.text: Ultrathin TiO2 nanosheets (dominant (001) facets, thickness about 2 nm), prepared by hydrothermal synthesis, have been shown to exhibit a H2 evolution rate as high as 7381 µmol h−1 g−1 under UV–vis light irradiation when exposing reactive (001) facets.[52] 2D TiO2 nanosheets for photo- and electrochemical oxidation of water have been additionally investigated by Kim et al., using a theoretical approach. They predicted that the activity can be further optimized by doping with transition metals.[53] A wide range of 3d, 4d, and 5d metal dopants were considered, showing that all metals helped reduce the overpotentials required to achieve water oxidation, and the rate determining step varies between the four-proton coupled electron transfer steps of the reaction, depending on the dopant.

sections.heading: 1.3.2. Photocatalysis
sections.text: 2D nanostructured thin oxide films are particularly relevant for the development of advanced electrodes in electrocatalytic or photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) devices and for photocatalytic applications. An example is represented by a thin film comprised of an array of vertically ordered TiO2 nanotubes,[54–58] modified by supported metal nanoparticles,[59] which were successfully used as advanced photoanodes in new photoelectrocatalytic cells to produce solar fuels.[60–64] Another example is photoanodes based on tantalum (oxy)nitride nanotube arrays, which can be used in PEC cells for the generation of solar fuels.[65–69]

sections.heading: 1.3.3. Energy Storage and Conversion
sections.text: Layered lithium metal oxides are interesting as high energy density cathode materials for battery technologies.[70] With increased O/M ratios, layered Li2MO3 has extra capacity via additional oxygen 2p electrons as compared with traditional LiMO2 materials.[71] Xie and co-workers used DFT+U calculations to predict that the covalency of the MO bond is a crucial descriptor for the stability and reversibility of redox activity.[72] Reversible anionic redox processes through hybridized oxygen is predicted to be achievable with late 4d and 5d metals. An alternative explanation for increased redox capacity of Li-rich layered materials was set out by Seo et al.[73] Using hybrid DFT calculations, the authors determined that specific Li–O–Li bridging geometries generate labile oxygen electrons lying near the Fermi energy, which are competitive with TM electrons for oxidation. This interpretation opens the possibility to surpass the theoretical limits set by the electron exchange capacity of the transition metal, by tuning the structure of the layered oxide.[71,74]

sections.heading: 1.3.4. Multifunctional Catalysis
sections.text: An example of multifunctional catalysis comes from a Rugrafted hydrotalcite (HT)-type layered hydroxide material for direct α-alkylation of nitriles with primary alcohols.[75] The reaction involves alcohol oxidation, hydrogen transfer, and Knoevenagel reactions, requiring both Ru (oxidation) and base sites, both of which are present on the HT. Yields close to 100% could be realized, depending on the alcohol. It is important to remark how this class of catalysts could be successfully applied in reactions requiring a multifunctional behavior to realize in one-pot (cascade reactions) conversions, which would otherwise require multiple separate steps, which come with the consequence of higher costs and environmental impact.

sections.heading: 1.3.5. Environmental Catalysis
sections.text: One example of environmental catalysis which utilizes the properties of layered oxide materials is that of Serwicka and Bahranovski, who developed a Pd-doped pillared montmorillonite clay material for the complete catalytic combustion of chlorinecontaining volatile organic compounds (CVOCs).[76] These species are a major source of environmental pollution, originating from industrial solvent waste. The catalyst was designed to make simultaneous use of the redox properties of the Pd dopant, and the acidic properties of the pillared clay, which are both predicted to be necessary for the reactivity.[76] It was observed that the pillared clay exhibited higher conversion than the commercial catalyst (Pd/Pt/γ-alumina) for at least the temperature range of 673–823 K, and reached 90% conversion at a 150 K lower temperature, implying better activity over a wider temperature range.

sections.heading: 1.3.6. 2D Zeolites
sections.text: Since the recent advent of controlled synthesis of 2D zeolites, exciting new possibilities have been opened for porous materials science. In contrast to other types of 2D materials, 2D zeolites can be synthesized by both bottom-up as well as top-down approaches, each of them having some advantages as well as limitations, as will be discussed later in more detail. New synthesis methodologies allow for a control of the physical characteristics of zeolite layers, and subsequent exploitation in a range of chemical applications. One example is in liquid-phase short chain aromatic alkylation. Another is the enhanced processing of larger molecules, utilizing 2D analogs of the MWW zeolite family, or the improved long-term performances of single and multilayer nanosheets with the MFI topology.[77] Detailed descriptions of the successful utilization of 2D zeolites and the current challenges in the field are given in Section 3. For details about zeolite framework types, see http://europe.iza-structure.org/IZA-SC/ftc_table.php.

sections.heading: 1.3.7. Encapsulation with Oxides
sections.text:
Fu and Bao[44] recently reviewed the possibilities for catalysis in the confined space below and between 2D materials, which are characterized by strong intraplanar bonding and

weak interplanar interactions. They denoted this new area as “chemistry under 2D cover,” which covers a diverse range of chemistry, from intercalation of molecules, to film growth on the underlying surface, to catalysis. The 2D confined space results in enhanced surface reactions, something in between the reactivity in the rigid void space of zeolites, and the flexible environment at the reactive sites of enzymes. It is important to remark that the intercalating space beneath supported nanolayers acts not only as a type of nanoreactor host space, but also induces a change in the reactive species.
The same concept may be applied to a thin porous 2D overlayer, which encapsulates supported catalytic nanoparticles (Figure 1, top). This concept has often been used to control accessibility to the active surface of the reactants, in order to avoid side reactions. An example is the work of Doman and coworkers[78] who encapsulated Rh nanoparticles (supported over a Ga-oxynitrate semiconductor) in a thin porous La-oxide shell to avoid contact between O2 and the Rh particles, while keeping the Rh surface accessible for protons. As a result, the formation of H2 in water splitting (Figure 1, bottom) was substantially enhanced. A number of similar examples may be found, including some industrial catalysts, which use a 2D-type porous surface layer to protect the underlying catalyst from poisoning.
In addition, Fu and Bao[44a] showed that the confined space may induce changes in the properties of the intercalated species, creating metastable forms that are otherwise difficult to prepare via traditional synthesis protocols. For example, unstable FeO nanoislands can be formed due to the confinement effect at interfaces between nanostructured oxides and metal substrates [Pt(111)].[79] The stabilization effect has been attributed to the
interface confinement energy, which is the energy lowering due to interfacing of the 2D structure with a substrate; it decreases in the order Pt(111) > Au(111) > graphene.[79b]

sections.heading: 1.3.8. Development of New Classes of Materials
sections.text: There are many new concepts emerging from the unique properties of 2D materials, which may lead to the discovery of new thin materials that push the boundaries of synthetic design and device performance. One rather interesting example is given by Druffel et al.[80] discussing the new class of 2D materials based on layered electrides, i.e., consisting of alternating layers of atoms and electrons. These ultrathin electrides were indicated as “electrenes.” Electrenes possess exciting properties, such as high electron mobility, high carrier concentrations, and low work functions. The potential applications include catalysis (in particular, electrocatalysis), batteries and transparent conductors.

sections.heading: 1.4. Why 2D and Layered Oxide Materials
sections.text:
A general question is why specific attention should be paid to these 2D and layered oxide materials, e.g., why they are relevant and “different” from other catalysts or bulk-type oxides. To discuss these aspects, it may be useful to first comment shortly that we consider here 2D oxides when only a virtually bidimensional structure (single layer) is present, while layered (e.g., multilayer) materials are those in which a 3D structure is
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (5 of 33)
present, but with weak interaction between the stacking layers. By reducing the interlayer interaction, for example by swelling or exfoliation, it is possible to change a layered structure to a 2D-prevailing structure and form rose-, urchin-like or analogous nanostructures.[81] The reverse process of more or less ordered stacking requires instead the formation of a weak bond (through a suitable “glue”) between the layers to overcome the energy barrier related to bond dissociation between the layer and a solvent in which the layers are dispersed. These chemical mechanisms of synthesis, opposite to physical methods such as atomic layer deposition (ALD), which are too expensive to synthetize industrial catalysts, were previously discussed by us, regarding the general concept of creating and mastering nanoobjects to design advanced catalytic materials.[16b] In addition, the reviews cited on layered oxides dedicate significant attention on the synthesis aspects. We have thus limited here the discussion on the synthesis procedures, leaving space to the analysis of synthetic and characterization aspects for 2D zeolite materials. We consider this latter class in detail because the synthesis procedures are different from those of the former materials and need thus to be specifically analyzed.
As indicated before, we limit discussion to oxide type materials because we consider this area the most relevant classes of materials from the catalytic industrial perspective. We have thus discussed here clays and LDHs, pillared clays, perovskites, and 2D zeolites. However, there is a main conceptual difference between the first group of layered or 2D oxides and 2D-type zeolites. In the second case, there is a relatively rigid structure due to the high energy required in changing the angle of SiO bond. There is, in this sense, a higher degree of flexibility in the first class of layered or 2D type materials, with a consequent higher degree of stabilizing defects and nonstoichiometries. While these are considered typically bulk-type properties, with relevance often underestimated in terms of catalytic behavior, the effect is enhanced in 2D type materials. Metal oxide ultrathin films are a new class of materials, whose properties deviate from (sometimes also not having the equivalent) the bulk counterpart.[81f ] Surface relaxation phenomena and interface chemistry are clearly different in 2D oxide materials with respect to the surface of a 3D-type equivalent oxide. Strain, band alignment, lattice dynamics, charge redistribution, and defects are some of the main characteristics. Furthermore, symmetry lowering at the interface creates new environments that are not accessible in the bulk equivalent. As a consequence, the physicochemical properties, starting from phonons to the redox, acido base, and reactivity catalytic properties are different and may be exploited to design improved or even novel catalysts. However, most of these aspects are still not rationalized up to now.
For practical applications, 2D and layered oxides do not create specific critical issues in the preparation, besides the usual care required in industrial preparation of pellets that the nanostructure is preserved and enough accessibility to the whole pellet is guaranteed. While often it is supposed necessary that 2D-type nanostructures are arranged in 3D interconnected geometries, industrial experience indicates that typically there is no specific need or cost advantage in having a preformed 3D arrangement of 2D-type units. Nevertheless, as mentioned before, reassembling nanosheets into 3D-type materials can be worthy as a further element to control the reactivity properties.
Sasaki et al.[81,82] have discussed, for example, how a variety of layered transition metal oxides and layered double hydroxides have been exfoliated into unilamellar nanosheets that can be then assembled or organized through various solutionphase processings to produce a range of nanostructured materials. Addition of electrolytes into a colloidal suspension of nanosheets promotes their restacking, yielding a flocculate. The nanosheets can also be deposited layer by layer with suitable polyelectrolytes to produce multilayer ultrathin films, in which the nanoarchitecture can be precisely controlled. These nanocomposites have properties different from those of the specific layers.
For applications such as photoactive materials, a general question is whether a 2D-like structure increases the possibility of grain boundaries between the sheets because these boundaries could create sites for charge recombination, decreasing solar efficiency.[83a–c] A structure with well-exposed nanosheets and minimization of their contact points (such as a rose-like nanostructure), in principle, exhibits a smaller grain boundary (per exposed surface area which can be illuminated) than the same oxide in the form of a compact layer formed of irregular nanoparticles. However, practice shows that 1D- or 2D-like nanostructures designed to minimize grain boundaries are typically less effective in terms of efficiency in light conversion than films composed by the same oxides in the form of nanoparticles, as shown for TiO2 solar cells.[58c] In fact, lowdimensional oxides, as previously commented, may be more intrinsically defective than the equivalent nanoparticles and this fact overcomes the reduced presence of grain boundaries. On the other hand, photocatalytic applications differ from photoinduced current generation applications (such as dye-sensitized solar cells) because defect trapping sites may create a mechanism to enhance the reactivity of the trapped charges (electron, holes) for photocatalytic reactions. In addition, by preferentially exposing specific crystalline planes, photo catalytic reactivity may be improved. Thus, in general there is no straightforward answer to the question of whether the presence of a 2D-like structure is beneficial for photocatalytic properties, and specific studies that have analyzed in detail the above-mentioned aspects are missing. For the same reason, quite scattered results are present in literature about the positive or negative role of the oxide nanostructure on the photoinduced behavior.

sections.heading: 1.5. Scope and Limits of the Review
sections.text:
This review aims to provide insight into the possibilities offered by 2D layered nanostructured oxide catalytic materials to address the challenges derived from the energy and chemistry transition. It is intended to provide the reader with an appreciation of the importance of the subject, a critical summary of recent developments and selected examples, and a guide to the relevant literature, with focus on emerging application areas. The general topics discuss the new development of 2D-type materials: i) to move toward solar-driven chemistry (e.g., based on the use of renewable energy rather than thermal energy from fossil fuel sources); ii) to intensify chemical processes by developing multifunctional catalytic materials able to drive
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (6 of 33)
complex multistage reactions; and iii) to improve selectivity to reduce resource usage in chemical processes. The approach is to analyze the overlap between the diverse range of 2D-type materials and their applications from an applied catalysis perspective.
The promising 2D materials were considered in this review in terms of their structural features, synthesis methods, and applications including (photo-, electro-) catalysis, molecular sieving, spintronics, etc. Due to the diversity in applications across these classes of material, we do not aim to create a comparative list of qualities rather we focus on the possibilities and connections between types. Where fair and direct comparisons may be made, we do so, for example, in the case of the relative Lewis acidities of 2D versus 3D microporous silicate materials of the same structural class.
Although emphasis is given here to 2D/layered materials, in contrast to the equivalent bulk-type materials, we have to remark that different other type of relevant nanostructured oxide exists, for example, branched nanostructured films for (photo)electrochemical water splitting or networks of nanoparticles. The common feature of such materials is that by controlling the nanostructure it is possible to obtain properties different from those of small 3D-type nanoparticles.[38,64a,c] It is worthwhile to comment, however, that in these areas a general knowledge-based approach on how to control the properties and catalytic reactivity based on the specific nanostructure characteristics is lacking. Most results are phenomenological and there is still no unequivocal literature showing that a specific nanostructure is preferable over others or the reasons for this difference. In many areas of investigations into oxide materials, theoretical modeling has proven useful, both in supporting experiment and in providing insight into the physical causes of observed behaviors. In this review, we do not aim to undertake a comprehensive review of theoretical work in the oxides field. However, we do include relevant theoretical results, in particular for cases where theory and experiment were used synergistically.
The changing scenarios in refinery and chemical production and their implications on the grand challenges for catalysis have been discussed elsewhere, in particular in the “Science and Technology Roadmap on Catalysis for Europe”[13c] and related publications.[13a,b] We will thus not comment here further on these aspects except to remark how this roadmap clearly showed that new 2D catalytic nanomaterials are one of the most important areas to expand catalysis concepts and upon which research areas we have to focus.

sections.heading: 2. 2D Nanostructured Oxide Films
sections.text:
2D nanostructured thin-film oxides display various interesting features, including an enhanced accessibility to active sites and improved mass transport when compared with nanoparticles or bulky catalysts. For photocatalytic applications, for example, excellent light harvesting and charge separation qualities make 2D materials particularly exciting. These materials may play an important role in the development of the next generation of catalytic electrodes for “solar-driven chemistry.” It is necessary, however, to combine proper control of the synthesis
parameters to optimize the chemical and engineering aspects of their design.[82,84,85]
These materials may be broadly categorized into four main categories. First, neutral oxide layered structures, which have efficacy as heterogeneous and water splitting catalysts in particular. Then negatively charged clay-type systems, which have been used as acidic supports and direct acid catalysts. Next, there are positively charged layered double hydroxides, which show a diverse range of uses as basic supports, precursors in neutral oxide catalyst synthesis, and fine chemical catalysts and intercalation catalysts. Finally, layered perovskite are materials that are interesting for photocatalytic applications. Section 2 follows this pattern in describing the 2D oxides mentioned above and their uses for energy and catalysis. 2D zeolites are separately described in Section 3.

sections.heading: 2.1. Neutral Layered Structures
sections.text: In this subsection, we begin with an overview of neutral metal oxide ultrathin films (UTF), which serve as model systems to probe the structural and electronic properties of layered oxide catalysts. This is an area where the collaboration between experiment and theoretical modeling can provide insights which deepen our understanding of the processes which govern activity. Next, the importance of the structure of the precursor to the final active phase of real-world neutral oxide catalysts is discussed in depth. 3D assemblies of 2D nanosheets are covered, for their unique properties. A summary of the utilization of neutral layered oxide materials for catalysis follows, focusing in particular on heterogeneous and water oxidation electro/ photocatalysis. Overall, neutral layered oxides possess a broad range of application directions in both catalysis and energy materials. Several fields, particularly in electrocatalytic water splitting are growing and they are likely to provide exciting results in the near future.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Ultrathin Films
sections.text:
Metal oxide ultrathin films are defined loosely as metastable 2D nanosheets of MxOy composition with thicknesses of less than around five layers. UTF are produced primarily by vacuumphase deposition methods, supported by conductive metal substrates and grown epitaxially. As such, they do not represent a class of materials applicable to large-scale catalysis. However, UTF are important model systems for understanding the physical origins of oxide interface chemistry. In a diverse range of areas including electronic/spintronic device applications,[86] the growth processes of metal oxides[87] and supported nanoparticle catalysis,[88] theory can bring insight into experimental results. As materials which are intermediate between molecules and bulk oxides, UTFs show several particular properties, such as high structural flexibility, and buckling-mediated charge transfer mechanisms. Exceptional tunability, through defect engineering, transition metal doping and control of thickness, make UTF excellent model systems for oxide catalysts. Several good reviews exist for a more in-depth discussion of UTF synthesis and characterization.[89]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (7 of 33)
Epitaxial growth of well-ordered mono- and bilayer UTF is controlled by factors which include the oxidation state of the metal, the lattice mismatch between film and substrate, film polarity, and the adsorption energy of the film to the surface.[89b] Large lattice mismatches promote symmetry breaking in the film. Competition between lattice expansion, polarity reduction and a preference to expose low surface energy layers to the vacuum leads to structural distortions in polar bilayer films. In the archetypal UTF case of FeO upon Pt(111), a hexagonal (111), polar buckled bilayer is formed, with iron atoms directly bound to the platinum surface, and the oxygen atoms comprising the vacuum termination layer.[90] Freund and coworkers observed an enhanced reactivity of the UTF toward CO oxidation, with respect to the Pt(111) surface, which is due to a rearrangement of the film in the presence of oxygen, from a bilayer to a trilayer.[91] The energetic profile for the conversion, and for the extraction of O from the exposed oxygen termination layer to form CO2 are both found with DFT+U calculations to be exothermic. For the UTF of MgO(100) upon Ag(100), activation of oxygen was proposed theoretically[92] and then confirmed experimentally.[93] This behavior originates from charge transfer through the film to adsorbed oxygen, making the system a promising low temperature CO oxidation catalyst. Another example where the atomistic scale structure of the UTF is coupled to its chemical properties comes from Merte and co-workers, who used DFT+U calculations to explain the experimentally observed difference in adsorption affinity toward NO between FeO(111)/Ag(100) and FeO(111)/ Pt(111) surfaces.[94,95] The calculations showed that the weaker FeO adsorption over Ag(100) drives a decrease in layer buckling, which in turn increases the accessibility of the iron atoms toward NO adsorption. Additionally, the weak bond between Fe and Ag leads to a barrierless local structural inversion of Fe and O atoms during NO adsorption, which is an activated process in the more strongly bound Fe-Pt case.
The importance of the electronic structures of conductive supports, oxide films, dopants, and supported particles has been investigated in UTF on systems such as Al in SiO2/ Mo(112)[96] and Li, Al, and Ni in MgO/Mo(100).[97] It was shown by Prada et al. that unlike in bulk oxides, the replacement of the metal ion in the film with a non-isoelectronic dopant does not lead to additional holes/electrons in the oxide states. The dopant retains its preferred oxidation state and the conducting support either gains or loses the electrons required to heal the oxide 2p states. This behavior means that the support acts as a selective electron source/sink, and the film can maintain localized charged sites for use in adsorption/catalysis.
The role of direct charge transfer through UTF to oxidesupported metal particles sheds light on an important concept in interface catalytic chemistry: that of controlling reactivity through activation of the nanoparticle. Pacchioni and co-workers used DFT calculations to predict that facile charge transfer from the conductive support through the film will induce a structural rearrangement of gold atoms and clusters, in order to maximize contact with the surface.[98] The important feature is explained to be the electron affinity of the supported particle and the work function of the donor support metal. These predictions were later verified experimentally for Au on an MgO(100) UTF, and shown to be thickness dependent.[88,99]
This concept has been applied to thicker films experimentally and theoretically,[100] by doping Mo-supported CaO films with Mo, which implies that it is a general, tunable property of supported oxide nanosheets to activate metal particles through charge transfer.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. The Role of Precursor Structure
sections.text:
Neutral layered oxides used in catalysis (MoO3, V2O5, etc.) form a great variety of structures. The role of the structure of the layered precursor system in the final activity of the catalyst can be seen in a number of examples, utilizing either neutral oxides or layered double hydroxides as precursors. A typical case is (VO)2P2O7, which is the active phase in the industrial process of n-butane oxidation to maleic anhydride.[101] The preparation of this catalyst in the active form strongly depends on the characteristics of the layered precursor phase (vanadyl hydrogen phosphate) and its intercalation chemistry.
Another interesting example is provided by porous FeNi oxide nanosheets, used as advanced electrochemical catalysts for water oxidation.[102] The topotactic transformation of the LDH ternary precursor, FeNi-LDH, is used to form a layered Fedoped NiO oxide which displays improved OER performance: a low overpotential of 213 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a small Tafel slope of 32 mV decade−1, and long-term stability. Interestingly, Long et al.[102] reported that the FeNi-LDH precursor shows only slightly poorer performance.
Zhao et al.[103] studied ultrafine NiO nanosheets (about 1.1 nm) stabilized by TiO2, which are derived from monolayer NiTi-LDH precursors. They concluded that the NiO nanosheets display outstanding performance in electrochemical water oxidation due to a high proportion of reactive NiO (110) facets and the presence of controlled vacancies (stabilized on nanosheets and by the interface with TiO2 nanosheets). Specifically, Ni3+ distorted octahedral sites are created, which are active in water oxidation. In addition, the heterostructure interface between the NiO and TiO2 nanosheets makes the NiO nanosheets more acidic, promoting the adsorption of OH−, which leads to improved OER activity.
These results clearly show the difficulty in the determination of the nature of the catalytic active sites and the relationship between the precursor, the nanosheet structure and the active sites. However, they also highlight the large range of possibilities in tuning the properties of 2D-type nano-oxides and improving their catalytic behavior. The role of the precursor in final catalyst activity is a crucial one, particularly in the case of hydroxides, and is one we will revisit in later sections.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. 3D Nanostructured Assemblies of 2D Nanosheets
sections.text:
V2O5 nanosheets can be produced by exfoliation and then manipulated to obtain interesting 3D architectures. For example, Zhu et al.[104] produced thin and flexible V2O5 nanosheets (thickness of about 4 nm) via the hydrothermal treatment of V2O5 powder with H2O2 at 190 °C and then transformed the nanosheets into 3D architectures by removal of water via a freeze-drying process. The result is a
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (8 of 33)
highly flexible V2O5 structure with a BET area of 133 m2 g−1, ultrathin walls, and multilevel pores (Figure 2a, left). The high surface area and porosity are beneficial for their use as supercapacitor electrodes. The performance is significantly enhanced with respect to bulk V2O5 and V2O5 nanosheets, exhibiting an energy density up to 107 W h kg−1 at a highpower density of 9.4 kW kg−1 (Figure 2a, right). Producing this type of 2D-3D nanostructured material not only influences the active (accessible) surface area but also induces a change in the catalytic reactivity by stabilizing defects and/or enhancing the exposition of specific crystalline planes. In fact, as shown by a similar type of 2D-3D nanostructured V2O5 material, although obtained from vanadium oxalate using aniline as the template and reducing agent, a high selectivity is observed in the direct liquid-phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. The reaction was performed in the presence of acetic acid as a solvent (Figure 2b), which is likely involved in the formation of peracetic acid, which is the proposed effective hydroxylation agent.[105] The nanostructuring leads to stabilization of reduced vanadium sites that are able to activate oxygen and oxidize acetic acid to peracetic acid. On the contrary, conventional V-oxide catalysts are not selective in this reaction. V2O5 nanosheets also exhibited photocatalytic H2 production activity superior to a commercially available V2O5 powder.[106] This is likely due to the more exposed (001) crystalline plane in the nanosheet. These examples show that 3D assemblies of 2D nanosheets can show improved performance with respect to the bulk oxides in various reactions, from charge storage (Figure 2a), to selective oxidation (Figure 2b) to H2 photogeneration (Figure 2c).

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Traditional Heterogeneous Catalysis
sections.text:
Nickel oxide nanosheets supported on porous clay heterostructures have been reported as catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane, with higher activity and selectivity toward ethylene production than NiO supported on silica.[107] At 450 °C, conversion is increased from 4% to over 20%, while selectivity is increased from around 20% to 80%. The increase
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (9 of 33)
in the catalytic performance was related to the modification of the Ni XPS signal (the satellite II/main peak ratio), which, together with other results, indicate that the formation of nanosheets changes the reducibility and O2-exchange characteristics of the NiO surface, leading to higher selectivity and activity. This demonstrates that changing from supported nanoparticles to nanosheets creates specific modifications to the surface reactivity.
Bi2WO6 nanosheets were reported as a robust catalyst in photo cyclization, specifically the synthesis of bioactive benzazoles (in the presence of cetyl trimethylammonium bromide).[108] As described in Section 1.3.2, ultrathin TiO2 nanosheets were found to show high H2 evolution rates, due to the exposed (001) facets of the layer. Free-standing NiO-MgOAl2O3 nanosheets derived from LDH grown onto FeCrAl fiber (to form a usable structured catalysts) were also successfully applied for dry reforming of methane.[109]
A further example of catalysis by nanosheets is the enhanced water gas shift (WGS) activity that results from deposition of ceria and titania nanoislands upon Au(111). It was found by Rodriguez et al.[110] that deposition of either oxide to coverage between 20% and 40% leads to maximum WGS activity, despite the inactivity of all constituent species bulk counterparts. XPS experiments which suggest a buildup of oxygen vacancies were confirmed by DFT results. Calculations show that the bare Au(111) surface is necessary to adsorb CO, while the oxide interface provides the oxygen for CO oxidation. The vacancy thus formed is then important for the H2O to H2 conversion necessary to complete the reaction. Several other examples of interface activity of oxides on metal substrates are known, including Cu–Ce oxides on Au(111) for
the WGS reaction[111] and CO oxidation at Rh(553) decorated with NiO2,[112] both of which have been modelled with DFT methods alongside experiment. These results show the particular importance of the interface between nanolayers and the support.

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Water Oxidation Catalysis
sections.text:
The application of neutral oxide nanosheets to water oxidation or splitting is an emerging area of research. Cheng et al.[113] used an array of NiO nanosheets on a carbon cloth as an OER electrode. The onset overpotential was found to be 295 mV, with a Tafel slope of 116 mV decade−1, which is in-line with, but slightly higher than those reported above for LDH-derived Fedoped NiO. Li et al.[114] prepared copper nanowires by anodic oxidation and thermal annealing, followed by coordination etching to produce a Co–Ni complex hydroxide, likely LDH-type, which grew as a nanosheet over the main Cu2O nanotube. This nanosheet acts as an OER catalyst, but by nitridation it is possible to also obtain an HER (hydrogen evolution reaction) catalyst (Figure 3). They could therefore be joined to form a water splitting system.
The 1D/2D nanotube/nanosheet morphology ensures a large electrochemically active surface area, good conductivity, and efficient charge transport during electrolysis. The obtained nanotubes show high stability and good current densities at low overpotentials (at an overpotential of about 280 mV, the current density in OER reaches 10 mA cm−2). When assembled together, the OER-HER system shows a current density of 11 mA cm−2 at a bias voltage of 1.65 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (10 of 33)
(RHE), and retains 74% of the original current density after 600 s. Therefore, the performance must be further improved, but it represents an interesting approach to create 1D/2D systems for water splitting and advanced electrodes.
Zhang et al.[115a] developed a Ni–Co layered double hydroxide cocatalyst to enhance O2 release with respect to a carbon nitride nanosheet material. A somewhat similar system, based on selfsupported nanoporous NiCo2O4 nanowires with cobalt- nickel layered oxide nanosheets for overall water splitting has been proposed by Yin et al.[115b] In 0.1 m KOH, this system produces a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 340 mV (1.57 V vs RHE) for OER. The same system also exhibits good catalytic performance in 0.5 M H2SO4 for HER, producing a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at overpotential of 52 mV and a Tafel slope of 34 mV decade−1.
Wu et al.[116a] recently proposed a mesoporous mixed oxide nanosheet array, comprised of Co-doped NiO/NiFe2O4 on a Ni foam as a highly stable, low water splitting system. The optimized system (Co6.25Fe18.75Ni75Ox) was found to exhibit excellent OER activity with a small overpotential of 186 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 38.5 mV decade−1. The same system also shows high HER activity, requiring an overpotential of 84 mV to deliver 10 mA cm−2, and again showing a low Tafel slope of 53.6 mV decade−1. The stability was tested over 1000 cycles for a duration of 12 h of galvanostatic measurements. It was found to be stable over this range, for both OER and HER. A two-electrode electrolyzer using bifunctional Co6.25Fe18.75Ni75Ox as both the anode and cathode demonstrates active and stable overall water splitting performance with a cell voltage of only 1.583 V at 10 mA cm−2. Note that Ni-hydroxide nanoplates themselves show interesting properties as HER catalytic components, particularly when doped with Pt.[116b]
Incorporation of catalytically important metals within ceria as single atom catalysts has been a recent area of interest for PEM fuel cell applications, both in the form of ceria nanoparticles and extended surfaces.[117] DFT+U calculations have shown that for a wide range of transition metals (Fe, Ru, Os, Co, Rh, Ir, Ni, Pd, Cu, Ag, and Au), the metal atoms can occupy square planar sites, coordinated by four oxygen atoms on the surface of ceria, and become oxidized. High stability against agglomeration suggests good potential as single atom catalysts. In particular, Pt deposited on nanostructured ceria films has been proposed as an anode catalyst system for PEM fuel cells, with high power densities observed experimentally.[118] Theoretical modeling has identified reversible switching between Pt2+ located in square planar {100} nanofacet sites, and metallic Pt sub-nanometer particles on the CeO2 surface between oxidation and reduction phases. These results are consistent with XPS experiments. The aforementioned materials, which are based on oxide nanosheets, represent an interesting direction for the development of advanced electrodes for “solar-driven chemistry.” However, it should be noted that the above results are based primarily on voltammometric or related measurements, or theoretical predictions, rather than on true experiments in water oxidation or splitting. The next step is to test their performance under realistic, operative conditions, in order to move from academic studies to development of functional electrodes and devices.

sections.heading: 2.1.6. Spintronics
sections.text: A further area which is worth noting is that of thin film spintronics.[119] Some recent work has suggested the viability of monolayer neutral oxide nanosheets for spintronic applications, primarily with theoretical methods. Kan et al. used a combination of DFT and Monte Carlo simulations to determine that MnO2 monolayers are intrinsic ferromagnets[86a] with a high Curie temperature of 140 K. Wang et al. reported that Mn vacancies lead to a conversion from insulating to half metal electronic structure in the same material with both experiment and hybrid DFT calculations.[86b] Increasing vacancy concentrations lead to a monotonic decrease in band gap, while half-metallicity is retained, suggesting that defect engineering of UTF may be appropriate for low-dimensional spintronic applications.

sections.heading: 2.2. Negatively Charged Layers
sections.text: In nature, layered compounds that contain negatively charged layers and interlayer charge-compensating anions are common, for example cationic clays (e.g., montmorillonite, hectorite and beidellite). The layers of clays are formed by the association of two or more tetrahedral and octahedral sheets, generally around Si and Al atoms. The simplest structure is that of talc; the dioctahedral analog is pyrophyllite. Talc structure is characterized by Si2O10 tetrahedral sheets and Mg(O,OH)6 octahedral sheets forming 2:1 layers. The layers are held together by very weak van der Waals forces. Montmorillonite is obtained by replacing Mg with Al in the octahedral layer of pyrophyllite. Other relevant smectites of dioctahedral clays are nontronite, beidellite and saponite. In general, various possibilities exist to tune and modify these “clay-based catalysts” to optimize their performance: i) different catalytic ions can be inserted within the interlayer space or in the pillars (in pillared clays), ii) functional nanoparticles or clusters can be hosted onto or within the clay nanostructure, and iii) acidity of the clay layers can be modified. Great potential exists in catalysis for composite and hybrid materials made from the combination of layered materials with other 0D, 1D and 3D materials, including quantum dots, nanotubes/fibers and nanoparticles, respectively. Examples of such combinations may be found in ref. [120]. However, the research interest on these aspects has decreased in the last years, being switched to other type of applications such as photovoltaic, photonic, electronic, electric, and magnetic properties. Two areas highlighted in this section, are uses in acidic catalysis, and as supports for transition metal catalysts.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Acid Catalysis
sections.text:
Negatively charged layered solids are used as catalysts for their acidic properties, particularly when exchanged with H+. Intercalation by polymeric metal hydroxides, followed by thermal treatments, allow pillaring of the layers to form microporous and thermally stable acidic compounds, used for example in the catalytic cracking of heavy fuels.[121] Modified montmorillonites (acid-treated) are also commercial catalysts for hydrocarbon
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (11 of 33)
cracking. Other relevant areas of application are for wastewater treatment,[122–125] and decomposition of volatile organic compounds (VOC).[126] These are established areas, with limited recent advances.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Supported Catalysts
sections.text:
Layered clays can also act as supports for transition metals (Zn2+, Fe3+, and Cu2+) which operate as Lewis acids in organic reactions (Friedel–Crafts acylation and alkylation of aromatic, etc.). One family of catalysts is known to possess tunable Brønsted versus Lewis acidity and has been commercialized with the trade name of Envirocats.[127,128] They offer interesting opportunities to realize in one-step reactions which require multifunctional sites. An interesting example is the Envirocat EPZ10 (12% ZnCl2/clay) catalyst, i.e., a montmorillonite (clay) modified with Lewis acid sites (ZnCl2). In the Biginelli reaction, i.e., the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H) (antitumoral, antiviral and antihypertensive), a yield of 84% could be achieved with EPZ10 (Figure 4).[129]
The same catalyst has been reported to show excellent performance in a number of other reactions, including the synthesis of coumarins by the Pechmann reaction under solvent-free microwave irradiation conditions,[130] the regioselective transformation of alkenes into iodohydrins and β-iodo ethers and further conversion of iodohydrins to epoxides under microwave irradiation,[131] the synthesis of 3-acetoacetylcoumarins,[132] and the synthesis of flavanones.[133] This exemplifies well the range of possible applications of this class of catalysts and their use in particular in the field of fine and specialty chemical synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.3. Positively Charged Layers
sections.text: The most relevant case of positively charged layers with compensating anions in the interlayer space is that of LDH (hydrotalcite-like, HT) compounds or anionic clays with the general formula: [M2+1−x M3+x (OH)2]x+ [Ax/n]n−·mH2O, where: 1) M2+ = Mg2+, Zn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, etc.; 2) M3+ = Al3+, Ga3+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Mn3+, etc.; 3) An− = CO32−, SO42−, NO3−, Cl−. HT are scarcely present in nature, and synthesis is achieved in the laboratory typically by coprecipitation.[134,135] These catalysts have a basic character and can be modified in many ways, by varying framework divalent and trivalent metal ions and interlayer anions, or by addition of ions, complexes or metal nanoparticles. LDH materials are flexible and widely used catalysts. In most of their applications, HTs are used as precursors to obtain homogenous mixed oxide nanoparticles, while examples in which their layered characteristics are directly exploited are more limited. In this subsection, we will consider the main applications of LDH materials, in: i) biomass conversion, ii) photocatalysis, iii) multistage reactions, iv) as supports for metal particle catalysts, and v) additional interesting applications. The final part will cover investigations in which the layered structure of LDH is directly utilized.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Biomass Conversion
sections.text:
In terms of application areas for LDH, the conversion of biomass-derived molecules is one of those in which interest is growing.[136] Reactions of interest in the area of biomass utilization include the following:[137]
- The oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (a main platform molecule derived from C6 sugars), for example to
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (12 of 33)
2,5-diformylfuran or to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (an important intermediate for the synthesis of polymers, pharmaceuticals and heterocyclic ligands). - Oxidation of glycerol, for the production of various valuable chemicals including dihydroxyacetone, glyceric acid, tartronic acid, mesoxalic acid, and dihydroxymalonic acid. - Oxidation of carbohydrates, such as glucose to gluconic and glucaric acids. - Hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol or other products, hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone. - Other reactions of relevance for biomass-derived product conversion, such as isomerization, dehydration, and aldol condensation.
It should be mentioned, however, that even if LDH catalysts are active in all these reactions, other catalytic systems show comparable performance. For this reason, while LDH-based catalysts are certainly an interesting option for the conversion of biomass-derived molecules, we are more cautious about the effective exploitability of these catalysts at an industrial scale than recent reviews on this topic.[136,137]

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Photocatalysis
sections.text:
LDH are emerging as promising candidates for photocatalysis in renewable energy production.[137] There are various potential advantages of 2D layered composite photocatalysts: i) specific directional paths for charge mobility can be present, which facilitate the transfer and separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, ii) a higher surface exposure with respect to the equivalent bulk material, and also a change in the material properties, iii) it is possible to form uniform multilayer structures (band gap tuning and heterojunction formation in 2D layered composites), and iv) it can be possible to form multifunctional hybrid systems. There are some examples in
the area of LDH photocatalysts[138] that take advantage of these opportunities, and therefore exploit the nanosheet characteristics of LDH materials.
One interesting example is given by ultrathin Ti-doped LDH nanosheets with a thickness of around 2.0 nm which incorporate M2+ cations (Ni2+ or Zn2+) into an LDH matrix.[139] They show interesting OER activity (visible illumination λ > 400 nm, AgNO3 as a sacrificial agent). NiTi-LDHs show the best results, and as shown in Figure 5a, a preparation by the reverse micelle method of a nanosheet structure leads to an OER activity (per m2 of surface area) about five times higher with respect to the same material with a bulk-type structure prepared by coprecipitation. The apparent quantum yield (about 65%) is also rather high.
Hunter et al.[140] showed the use of pulsed-laser ablation in liquid to produce [Ni–Fe]-LDH catalysts with high OER activity, which can be further promoted with intercalation of ions with Lewis acidity (Ti4+ and La3+) obtaining a low overpotential of 260 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Nitrite ions bound by the N-atom to edge-site iron promote a linear increase in the TOF, indicating that edge-site Fe plays a major role in water oxidation. This suggests that in the FeNi-LDH catalysts, the main role of the nanosheet structure is to provide the tight coordination for the iron sites located on the nanosheet edges, with the intercalated ions or molecules within the interlayer space operating as tuning elements for the charge density or coordination of these edge sites.
A different strategy is to prepare nanohybrids, also utilizing the layered structure. An example was reported by Gunjakar et al.[141] that used, for visible light-induced O2 generation, self-assembled materials prepared between exfoliated Zn–Cr-LDH 2D nanosheets and POM nanoclusters (W7O246− and V10O286−) acting as an electron acceptor. Figure 5b reports a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) image of the most active Zn–Cr-LDH/polyoxotungstate nanohybrid, with an indication of the OER activity with visible light excitation. Although the experimental conditions are not exactly the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (13 of 33)
same, the nanohybrid approach appears not to outperform the nanosheet approach, although there is still a broad scope for possible improvements.
To optimize OER behavior, Xu et al.[142] computationally studied various mixed oxidation state MIIMIII-LDH for the oxygen evolution reaction. The calculated band structure indicates that Mg- and Zn-based LDHs are ultraviolet responsive, while Co- and Ni-based LDHs are responsive to visible light, due to their differing band gaps. NiGa-, CoAl-, ZnAl-, and NiAlLDHs are all found to have valence band maxima above the oxidation potential of water, which is necessary for OER activity. However, of these four LDHs, only the CoAl-LDH has a sufficiently low overpotential for water oxidation to proceed. In the work, experimental observations confirmed the theoretical result, that CoAl-LDH is indeed an efficient oxygen evolution photocatalyst, with an O2 generation rate of 973 µmol h−1 g−1. Furthermore, the MgAl and ZnAl forms were found to be inactive, as predicted.
LDHs have also been reported to show interesting photocatalytic H2 generation behavior. One example shows that the intercalation of iron into MgAl-LDHs leads to activities in the production of hydrogen of up to 493 µmol g−1 h−1 under irradiation by visible light.[143] This can be explained by the beneficial incorporation of FeO6 units in the LDH, for which the conduction band energy becomes more negative with respect to the normal hydrogen electrode. This electronic change facilitates electron transfer to adsorbed H+, to evolve H2. Xia et al.[144] reported that CuMgCr-LDHs exhibited the narrowest band gap and the largest surface area of the CuMgXLDH class (X = Cr, Al, Fe, and Ce). Consequently, the chromium-doped LDH shows the highest efficiency for hydrogen production under visible light of this group, with a yield of 452.9 µmol g−1 h−1.
An alternative strategy to direct photocatalysis of LDH, is to utilize the localized surface plasmon resonance (by Au and Ag nanoparticles) to enhance the visible light activity of LDHbased photocatalysts. Nanocomposites of Au/LDH (LDH = ZnAl, ZnAlCe) are effective at H2 generation in mixed solvents of water and methanol. The role of cerium in the later may be to drive oxidation of the supported gold, from Au0 to Au3+. This would enhance hydrogen evolution under irradiation, by pushing the additional electrons into the LDH conduction band, which in turn increases reactivity to form H2.[145]
In addition to nanocomposites comprised of metal nanoparticles with the LDH, Complex organic anions such as 4,4-diaminostilbene-2,2-disulfonate (DAS) and 4,4-dinitrostilbene-2,2-disulfonate (DNS) can be introduced. This was done for Zn2Al-LDH, producing an intercalated organic–LDH system.[146] The DAS(50%)–DNS/LDHs composite was seen to exhibit a broad UV–vis light absorption and fluorescence quenching. This result implies that there is a photoinduced electron transfer between the donor (DAS) and acceptor (DNS) ions. As a consequence of this characteristic, the material is used as a photoanode, exhibiting a good photogenerated current (4.67 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V vs SCE) under UV–vis light illumination, together with photoelectrochemical water splitting. In this case, the LDH is used to host donor–acceptor species between the layers. There are thus several possible strategies by which LDH layered structure could be exploited, and
indications should be considered only initial. There is still a substantial effort necessary to optimize these systems in water splitting, particularly using visible light.
It is worthwhile to mention the emerging area of photocatalytic CO2 reduction using LDHs. Zhao et al.[147] used ultrathin Zn- containing LDH nanosheets as photocatalysts for the conversion of CO2 into CO. DFT calculations indicate that oxygen vacancies (V0) are created by decreasing the LDH thickness. The high photocatalytic activity is explained to be due to these oxygen vacancies, as they lead to coordinatively unsaturated Zn+ sites in the sheet, which in turn drive the reaction. An alternative approach for CO2 photoreduction is to combine plasmonic photocatalytic nanoparticles (Au, Ag) with the LDH layers to increase performances under visible light.[148]
LDH have also been incorporated in a tandem photoreactor cell (called a reverse photofuel cell) to reduce CO2 to methanol. Morikawa et al.[149] combined on the two sides of the tandem photoreactor cell two photocatalysts: WO3 for water oxidation and LDH modified by Zn, Cu, and Ga for CO2 photoreduction to methanol (Figure 6). The two hemicells were separated by a polymer electrolyte film. The LDH photo catalyst was based on earlier studies[150] on ZnCuGaLDH photocatalysts for the same reaction. The best performances (0.49 µmolMethanol h−1 gcat−1) were obtained using [Zn1.5Cu1.5Ga(OH)8]+2(CO3)2−·mH2O when the interlayer carbonate anions were replaced with [Cu(OH)4]2−. The methanol selectivity was found to be 88%. Interestingly, the authors report that Cu species in the interlayer region were more active than octahedral Cu sites, which are situated in the layer, by a factor of around 6 times. The photocatalysis is driven by a direct electronic transition from 2p states in the oxygen of the layer, to metal 3d, 4s, or 4p sites.
Liu and Zhang[151] reported various other examples of LDHbased photocatalysts for H2 generation or CO2 reduction. Finally, Teramura et al.[152] reported on the photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO with simultaneous water oxidation to O2 using LDHs with an M2+/M3+ ratio of 3 (M2+ = Mg2+, Zn2+, Ni2+; M3+ = Al3+, Ga3+, and In3+). They found the MgIn-LDH to have the highest activity of the tested materials, with an activity, which varies significantly with the quality of the layer stacking.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Multistage Reactions
sections.text:
An example in which hydrotalcites are used in a similar manner to clays to selectively realize complex multistage reactions is shown in Figure 4b. This example includes four steps in one pot: acid-catalyzed esterification, deacetalization, basecatalytic aldol condensation and epoxidation.[26,75] This tandem deprotection-aldol reaction is widely used in fine and specialty chemical synthesis and requires an acid and base couple, which typically self-neutralize. However, a Ti4+-exchanged montmorillonite (Ti4+-mont) and a hydrotalcite are used successfully in combination, due to their strong Brønsted acid and Lewis base sites, which are required for the tandem reaction.[75]
Thanks to the specific layered structure of these two catalysts and the location of the active sites, this Ti4+-mont/HT catalyst achieves a 93% yield of the target molecule, benzylidene malononitrile.[75]
