sections.heading: 2.3.4. Supported Catalysts
sections.text:
A general overview of the recent progress in supported catalysts by using LDHs as supports/precursors, has been given by Feng et al.[136]
For redox reactions, oxidation or hydrogenation, the active components are metal nanoparticles, especially based on noble metals (Au, Pt) for oxidation and either noble or transition metals (Cu, Ni, in particular) for hydrogenation. The LDH acts primarily as a medium-strength basic support, which avoids, or otherwise limits side reactions (in particular, the critical reaction of humin formation) and influences the characteristics of the support nanoparticles as well.
The adsorption of gold sub-nanometer clusters on a model LDH support of Mg(OH)2 has been investigated theoretically, with a DFT global optimization strategy.[153] It was observed that the surface OH groups have a profound effect on the cluster structure. Tilted planar geometries are preferred for Au10, while compact geometries become distorted by the surface. Strong AuOH bonds of around 0.8 eV per bond are formed, with an overall charge transfer to gold, which is predicted to facilitate oxidation chemistry. Such activity has been confirmed for low temperature CO oxidation by Li et al.[154] over layered MgAl-LDH, for deoxygenation of epoxides over hydrotalcite[155] and for oxidation of 1-phenylethanol to acetophenone on NixAl-LDH (x = 1–4).[156]
Zhao et al. showed for a layered CoAl LDH that well-dispersed supported Pd nanoparticles show high electrocatalytic activity toward ethanol oxidation[157] which is in agreement with DFT calculations. Charge transfer of around 0.1 electrons per palladium atom from surface hydroxyl groups generates a partially anionic cluster, in a manner related to the activation of metal particles on UTF oxide films. This particle charging then facilitates ethanol bond cleavage.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Additional Applications
sections.text:
Many reviews have discussed the use of HTs as catalysts in fine/specialty chemical syntheses.[158–161] An additional recent application is found in electrocatalytic OER catalysis. Fan et al. found a nickel-vanadium monolayer LDH to have water oxidation electrocatalytic activity comparable with the best NiFeLDH materials.[162] DFT+U calculations were performed for the adsorption and four oxidation steps, with the total free energy difference pinned to the experimental value of 4.92 eV to avoid the problematic calculation of the dioxygen energy. It was found that the RDS is H2O + *O → *OOH + H+ + e−, but that the RDS and the overpotential are dependent on the doping metal, which opens the possibility of improved doped nickel layered hydroxide OER catalysts. Other reviewed fields in which HTs are used as catalysts are biodiesel production, where their base
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (15 of 33)
properties are used,[163,164] H2 production,[165] nitrogen oxide abatement,[166] catalytic oxidation of alcohols,[167] dry reforming of methane[168] and other reactions relevant for the environment protection.[76] It should be noted, however, that the HT is often used just as the precursor of the effective catalyst.

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Utilizing the Layered Structure
sections.text:
In most of the above applications, LDHs have been used either as a basic-type support, which eventually operates as a co-catalyst, or as precursor phase. The cases where the presence of nanosheets or of a layered structure is directly exploited are quite limited. One of the requirements for this is that the reaction conditions allow for the preservation of the layered structure. However, it is also necessary to prove that due to interlayer confinement of the active species and cooperative catalytic effects, the layered structure provides specific conditions that improve the catalytic performance.
Examples in which the layered structure of the LDH is important in the final activity of the catalyst, but do not meet the requirements of direct application of the layers include the MgAl-HT, modified by substitution of Mg or Al with other transition ions (Co, Zn, and Cu).[136] This material is active in isomerization, dehydration and aldol condensation. The tuning of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites is an important factor in optimizing the catalytic performance. Anions located in the interlayer space of LDHs can also act as the active center for isomerization. Another such example is that of Gérardin et al.,[169] who reported immobilization of negatively charged Ni colloidal particles into the interlayer space of MgAl-LDH sheets, and then calcination and reduction of the sample at high temperature to prepare catalysts for methane reforming. The LDH layered structure therefore has the role of obtaining a good dispersion of Ni and limiting its sintering, rather than playing a direct role in the catalytic behavior. A further example is that of Barrabés et al.[170] who have intercalated negatively charged copper hydroxy citrate colloids and then hexachloroplatinate species into an LDH, to obtain, after thermal treatment, a bimetallic PtCu catalyst for the hydrogenation of nitrate anions. They report better catalytic performance from their anion exchange method than the best catalyst produced via conventional impregnation synthesis. This better performance is due to a higher dispersion of Pt and Cu nanoparticles under reduced conditions. In all of these cases, the layered structure is exploited in the preparation phase, rather than directly in the active catalyst. There is not always a clear distinction between these aspects, and further work is necessary to fully characterize these catalysts in future.
A potential direct application of the layered nature of LDHs is exemplified by including immobilized anionic complexes, for example polyoxometalates (POM), within the hydroxyl-rich HT layers.[171] In epoxidation reactions, LDHs provide the possibility to avoid epoxide hydrolysis, which is an unwanted side reaction. The intercalation of POMs into the interlayer galleries of LDHs can also potentially inhibit side reactions, such as deactivating dimerization or self-oxidation reactions. A specific example includes catalysts prepared by the immobilization of [WZn3(ZnW9O34)2]12− oxometallate anion in MgAl-LDH.[172]
These catalysts show up to 99% epoxide selectivity, 95% H2O2 efficiency and a TOF up to about 4 × 104 h−1 in the epoxidation of allylic alcohols. This remarkable result is attributed to high stability, which may be related to the confinement effect within the LDH layers, and a high dispersion. However, further proof is necessary. As noted in Section 2.3.3, the combined Ti4+doped Mont/HT catalysts also use the layered structure directly.
In conclusion, despite the large potential in terms of tuning the characteristics of LDH-based materials and the many efficient catalysts that have been developed based on LDHs, there is still a lack in the design of catalysts, which would effectively exploit the layered characteristics of these materials, beyond their use as supports or precursors. As discussed before, regarding oxide nanosheets, there are possibilities to stabilize ions within the nanosheet or at the edge in a metastable coordination environment, which may work in cooperation with the hydroxyl and basic sites of LDH layer and of anionic species intercalated within the layers, Therefore, although these catalysts are well known, there is still great potential to develop new and innovative catalytic materials.

sections.heading: 2.4. Layered Perovskites
sections.text:
An important class of perovskites are the Ruddlesden–Popper (RP) phases, which consist of perovskite layers with cornersharing BO6 octahedra that are separated by cations in the interlayer space. The RP phases have the formula AO(ABO3)n and A atoms occupy interstitial sites between octahedral layers. Examples of interesting materials for catalytic water splitting are: i) titanate as Sr3Ti2O7, ii) tantalate as H2La2/3Ta2O7, and iii) niobate as Sr2Nb2O7. The layered structure reduces electron–hole recombination and thus plays a crucial role, together with other characteristics such as cation valency and layer thickness, in determining the activity in water splitting, as shown in Figure 7.[173]
Various layered perovskite photocatalysts have been reported to show interesting behavior in H2 photoproduction. SrBi2Nb2O9 was indicated as the most active of a series of Abi2Nb2O9 samples, where A = Ca, Sr, Ba, by Li et al.[174] A Bi5Ti3FeO15 layered perovskite exhibiting an Aurivillius phase
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (16 of 33)
was indicated as preferable under visible light by Jang et al.[175] Protonated layered perovskite oxides H1.9K0.3La0.5Bi0.1Ta2O7, H1.6K0.2La0.3Bi0.1Nb2O6.5 and H-Abi2Ta2O9 (A = Ca, Sr, Ba, K0.5La0.5) were indicated by Chen et al.,[176] while Soldat et al.[177] analyzed the properties of Cr2O3 nanoparticles deposited on (111)-layered perovskite Ba5Ta4O15 for photocatalytic water splitting. Domen and co-workers,[178] who were among the first to remark upon the properties of layered perovskite type materials for water splitting,[179] put attention more recently into a new layered perovskite (CsBa2Ta3O10) and its conversion to nitrided Ba2Ta3O10 nanosheets. The same group[180a,b] proposed SrNbO2N and HLaTiO4− xNx, while K2CaNaNb3O10 was indicated by Oshima et al.[180c] to be an OER-active system. N-doping of the layered niobate is found to greatly improve the visible-light photocatalytic activity.[181]
An example of the use of theory to rationalize the catalytic activity of perovskites comes from Suntivich et al., who revealed that the occupation of the transition metal d-band eg state is a descriptor for water-splitting activity.[182] The activity is determined by the oxygen adsorption energy to each of the intermediates, which is in turn governed by the filling of the hybridized state formed between metal d states and adsorbate oxygen states.[183] Grimaud et al. showed with combined electrochemical and DFT+U characterization that the covalency of the MO bond in perovskites can control both the activity and the mechanism of OER reactions.[184] Highly covalent structures exhibit states with high oxygen 2p character near the Fermi energy, which can be directly involved in redox steps, providing additional reaction pathways to water splitting. These calculations were performed using the same method as Lee et al.,[185] who consider the thermodynamic effects of applied potential and pH using the computational standard hydrogen electrode method.[186] For photocatalytic applications of perovskites, DFT methods have been extensively applied in the analysis of oxide structure and electronic properties, in particular for band structure calculations. For an overview, we direct the reader to the review of Liu and Sohlberg.[187]
Another example of the joint efforts of experiment and theory in perovskite research is that of layered perovskite oxychloride Bi4NbO8Cl, which has recently been suggested as a stable visible light responsive photocatalyst for water splitting.[188] DFT studies[189] show that water adsorbs favorably on the (100) surface of the Bi4MO8X series (for which M = Nb and Ta, X = Cl, Br, and I) and the electronic properties are beneficial for water splitting. The band gaps are indirect and primarily comprised of O 2p states. This both aids against photocorrosion and enhances electron–hole separation. The lowest calculated overpotential for OER is 0.69 eV, which is lower than those of many commonly used OER photocatalysts.
As it is clear from this brief analysis, a single or restricted class of layered perovskites on which to focus attention as materials for water splitting has not yet been identified. Most are synthesized at very high temperatures by solid-state reactions, and thus have low surface areas. Processing for preparing the electrodes also presents issues, although some advances have been made recently in this direction. Bloesser et al.[190] showed that (111)-layered Ba5Ta4O15 nanofibers may be prepared with tailored diameters between 100 and 300 nm by electrospinning methods. Photocatalytic water splitting studies revealed an optimum fiber diameter (161 nm).
In conclusion, the wide variety of potential perovskite-based catalytic materials is a positive from the point of view of catalyst design, but work is necessary to narrow the field of this promising class of oxides and identify stable, active, high surface area catalysts for application.

sections.heading: 3.1. Features of 2D Zeolites
sections.text:
Zeolites are well known as catalysts and adsorbents used in numerous industrial applications.[191] Despite a high level of understanding of zeolite chemistry and catalytic behavior, there are still many challenges in traditional (catalysis, adsorption, and separation) and emerging (electronics and optics, and energy storage) fields of applications, which cannot be solved using conventional 3D zeolite materials: i) a slow molecular transport in microporous systems, which can be eliminated by using hierarchical materials;[192] ii) the adjustment of zeolite structure and pore architecture at the nanometer scale, which remains a challenge despite the existence of many different approaches for the design of hierarchical materials;[192–195] iii) the synthesis of selectively permeable zeolite membranes with nanometer-sized thickness for high-flux molecular sieving.[196] The problems mentioned above can be overcome by 2D zeolites (also called layered or nanosheet zeolites) with the thickness of the layers of typically just a few nanometers.[197–199]
The synthesis of the 3D zeolite with MWW topology (MCM22) was first performed more than 20 years ago via the topotactic condensation of the layered precursor (MCM-22P) composed of regularly stacked lamellas with a thickness of one unit cell.[200] Taking into account that the zeolite layer with a thickness of only one unit cell could be considered as the unique zeolite building block, the discovery of the MCM-22P layered zeolite stimulated numerous studies devoted to organization and manipulation of such layered assemblies toward new materials and even zeolites (Figure 8).[201] In particular, the possibility to vary the interlayer distance using swelling[202] followed by pillaring with various inorganic[203] or organic[204] props, or exfoliation[205] was demonstrated.
With respect to potential applications, 2D zeolites should possess as a high aspect ratio as possible. Determination of the layer thickness and wrinkling for such materials becomes crucial because these properties significantly influence their performance in separation, adsorption, and catalysis (see below). Properties of 2D zeolites can be controlled by the alteration of the synthesis procedure and their accurate quantification is essential.[206,207] Zeolite nanolayers are thicker than other wellrecognized 2D materials such as graphene and its derivatives, MXenes or metal dichalcogenides and halogenides.[208–210] Properties of 2D zeolites are discussed below, including structural features, adsorption characteristics, and acidic properties.
Measurements of the thickness of zeolite layers can be performed by atomic force microscopy (AFM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and its variations (STEM, HAADFSTEM, etc.), or X-ray reflectometry (XRR) (Figure 9).[211–213]
Most of these methods suffer from limitations such as the necessity to prepare the periodic multilayer (for XRR), which is
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (17 of 33)
not achievable for most of the 2D zeolites, high electron beam sensitivity of 2D zeolites in transmission electron microscopy, or unavoidable imaging artifacts that depend on the curvature of the layers (AFM). Therefore, methods for reliable evaluation of the thickness and structure of 2D zeolites are still needed. Kumar et al. reduced the beam damage of zeolites and characterized the atomic structure of a 2D zeolite using quantitative mapping of the reciprocal lattice.[214] This study included determination of crystal structure, sheet thickness, and the level of wrinkling. Evaluation of deviations from the wrinklefree structure of 2D materials is important because such deviations can affect the structure of internal and external surfaces of layered materials. Atomic-scale wrinkles can be found using STEM,[215] and quantitative mapping of the reciprocal lattice can be achieved using a large-angle tilt series of electron diffraction patterns. The change in intensity of the diffraction spot as a function of the tilt angle was considered as a characteristic of thickness. Changes in the shape of the diffraction spot were used to determine the extent of wrinkling. This approach was applied to a 2D zeolite with MFI topology—the layered form of zeolite ZSM-5 widely used in the industry as the catalyst or support material for various catalytic phases.[216] It was found that the thickness of MFI layers is about 3 nm, corresponding to 1.5 unit cells, in agreement with HAADF-STEM images. The wrinkling of MFI nanosheets was nonuniform and layers were wrinkled anisotropically with up to 0.8 nm average surface roughness. Similarities and differences in adsorption properties of 2D and 3D zeolites have been investigated systematically using adsorption measurements and molecular simulations, in particular for molecules relevant for catalytic processes (e.g., hydrocarbons). Xu et al.[217] compared the adsorption of 2,2-dimethylbutane, n-hexane, and n-nonane in hierarchical self-pillared MFI (self-pillared pentasil, SPP) and in its conventional 3D analog. 2,2-Dimethylbutane adsorption rates and equilibrium adsorption reflects the differences in porosity between 2D and the conventional MFI zeolite. Adsorption in layered material was more complex due to the so-called “edge effects” for longer n-hexane and n-nonane adsorbates. Only a fraction of adsorbates is confined in the microporous interior, while the remaining molecules are located in the mesopores. Bai et al.[218] performed molecular simulations of the adsorption of the same alkanes; a multistep mechanism was found to be responsible for the edge effect. The first adsorption step in 2D zeolite nanosheets occurs in micropores, similarly to the adsorption in 3D zeolites. However, the second adsorption
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (18 of 33)
step takes place at the pore mouths and corners formed by 2D nanolayers. The final step is the capillary condensation in the mesopores. It is worthwhile to note that for the studied 2D MFI zeolite, the adsorption in the micropore region at low coverages was practically unaffected by the existence of mesopores. This is an important observation with respect to the catalyst selectivity since it is generally expected that shape selectivity could be lower in layered 2D zeolites than conventional 3D zeolites.[219]
Surface properties of 2D zeolites derived from UTL and ITH were investigated computationally by Hermann et al.[220] Interaction energies of small probe molecules (CH4, CO2, H2O, H2, and N2) were calculated for corresponding 2D and 3D zeolites at highly accurate levels of theory, including the vdW-DF/CC method derived from the DFT/CC correction scheme.[221] Small molecules without significant permanent dipoles or quadrupoles interact with the 2D zeolites with a similar strength as with the 3D zeolites; decreased dispersion interaction with 2D zeolites (due to lower density) is just compensated by the contribution from hydroxyl groups present on the surface. Interaction of molecules with a larger permanent dipole or quadrupole (CO2 and H2O) is stronger with the 2D zeolites than with the 3D zeolites due to increased electrostatic interaction with surface silanols.
Understanding of the location, structure, and activity of acid sites in 2D zeolites is crucial for proper assessment of advantages and disadvantages of 2D zeolites with respect to conventional 3D zeolites. The ratio between external and internal surfaces increases by orders of magnitude in 2D zeolites as compared to 3D ones. Consequently, a large fraction of acid sites (either Brønsted or Lewis) are located relatively close to the surface silanol groups in 2D zeolites.[222] Figure 10 shows an example of a CO molecule interacting with the Li+ Lewis site on the external surface of 2D MFI. In addition to the interaction with Li+, the CO molecule is weakly interacting with surface silanol groups in its close proximity and this can clearly influence the catalytic activity of the acid site.
Lewis acid sites in 2D IPC-1P zeolite were investigated computationally at the DFT level.[223] In particular, Li+ cation sites in 2D IPC-1P and corresponding 3D zeolites containing the
same dense 2D layers as IPC-1P (UTL, OKO and PCR) were investigated and their Lewis acidity was classified based on the adsorption of the CO probe molecule. The higher CO adsorption enthalpy and CO stretching frequency of the CO adsorption complex is characteristic of Li+ sites with higher Lewis acidity. Small Li cations preferably occupy extra-framework sites on the channel wall in 3D zeolites[224] and there is only a small effect on the Lewis acidity of corresponding sites in 2D zeolites. However, Li+ sites on the intersection of two channels having the highest Lewis acidity[225] do not exist upon the 3D → 2D transformation and Li+ becomes tightly coordinated to framework oxygen atoms and adjacent silanol oxygens, and thus the Lewis acidity of these Li+ cations is significantly decreased. Lewis acidities of 3D and 2D zeolites with MFI and MWW structure were also investigated computationally, adopting the same strategy as for IPC-1P/UTL materials referred above.[226] While only minor difference between the Lewis acidity of extraframework Li+ in 2D and 3D was found for MWW, the Lewis acidity decreased in 2D MFI compared to 3D MFI. Together with the results reported above for IPC-1P/UTL it leads us to conclude that the decrease in the Lewis acidity of 2D zeolite with respect to its corresponding 3D analog becomes greater for 2D materials with: i) thinner layers and ii) larger concentration of surface silanols. Both of these effects improved coordination of Li+ (or other cations) with the framework and the decreased Lewis acidity.
The structure of alkali metal cations in the hierarchical FAU zeolite was investigated by a combination of computational and experimental tools.[227] Coordination of alkali metal cations (Na+ and K+) and their ability to bind CO were compared for regular 3D FAU, hierarchical USY, and 2D FAU. A strong effect of silanol groups present on the external surface was reported.
The Brønsted acidity of 3D and 2D zeolite CHA was investigated computationally by Ribicki and Sauer.[228] Absolute deprotonation energies were calculated at the DFT level of theory for zeolites with various Si/Al ratios. Much lower deprotonation energies (10–20%, depending on the Si/Al ratio) were found for 2D zeolites and it was ascribed to the smaller dielectric constant of an ultrathin dielectric in the vacuum compared to that of the corresponding bulk CHA, which led to an improved stabilization of thus formed charge. Brønsted acidities of various 3D and 2D zeolites were discussed further based on the calculated deprotonation energies, OH stretching frequencies, and adsorption enthalpies of small probe molecules.[227] Significantly higher intrinsic acidity of 2D zeolites than that of 3D zeolites was apparent from the differences in deprotonation energies. Acid sites on external and internal surfaces of zeolite Beta were investigated at the DFT level of theory.[228] Important differences between the properties of the Brønsted site on internal and external surfaces were shown. In particular, Si–O(H)–Al bridging groups are present in micropores close to the pore mouth while thermodynamically most stable sites are located on the external surface and they are formed by water molecules adsorbed on three-coordinated aluminum.[229,230]
The accessibility of acid sites for bulky molecules in pillared 2D zeolites with MWW and MFI topology has been assessed by adsorption of different probe molecules including small size dimethyl ether and pyridine, and large 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine, which cannot enter the MFI micropores.[70,231] Liu et al.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (19 of 33)
used base titration (with pyridine and 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine) during ethanol dehydration reaction to investigate the surroundings of active sites in lamellar MWW and MFI zeolites and in their 3D analogs.[231a] The strength of the active sites in a different location was assumed to be the same. Saturation of acid sites with pyridine (which is assumed to bind to both, internal and external acid sites) resulted in complete suppression of the ethanol dehydration. On the contrary, saturation with 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine led to the rate loss in the range of 0–67%, depending on the pore architecture. This finding can be explained by the fact that the bulky 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine cannot adsorb on the Brønsted acid sites located in micropores. 2,6-di-tert-Butylpyridine uptake after titration saturation was consistent with the decrease in dehydration rate, which excludes the possibility that the reaction rate decreases due to pore blocking by the bulky probe molecules. Thus, the ratio of active sites located on the external and internal surfaces can be evaluated (it should be noted that reliability of this assumption is questionable since it does not take into account the difference in the activity of acid sites). It was found that only up to 8% of acid sites are accessible for 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine in 3D zeolites, while pillared MWW and MFI possessed 67% and 30% of external Brønsted acid sites, respectively. Thus, if the reaction involves small reactants, Brønsted acid sites in 2D and 3D zeolites behave almost identically, while layered materials can provide enhanced catalytic activity for larger molecules.
A deeper differentiation and quantification of external acid sites located on the external surface or at the pore mouth regions in pillared MFI and MWW materials was performed by Wu et al.[232] In addition to the titration with dimethyl ether to evaluate overall acid site concentration, methanol dehydration in the presence of 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine or triphenylphosphine was tested. While 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine (with a diameter of 7.9 Å) can access both the acid sites on external surface and at the pore mouths, triphenylphosphine (with a diameter of 9.4 Å) can only access the former. Thus, the methanol dehydration rate loss in the presence of 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine or triphenylphosphine corresponds to the sum of surface and pore mouth acid sites or the sole fraction of external surface acid sites, respectively. In agreement with the earlier reports,[231] Wu et al. found that the sum of external acid sites concentrations (surface + pore mouth) was lower for MFI in comparison with MWW: pillared MFI possesses about 32% of surface acid sites and only 6% of those located at pore mouths, while MWW analog have comparable amount of active centers of both types (33% and 31%, respectively). The difference can be assigned to the 12-ring pore mouths in MWW, which provide a larger number of acid sites in comparison with MFI zeolite.
Acid properties of 2D zeolites were also investigated using the 31P NMR technique.[233] Multiple types of Brønsted acid sites with various strengths were found in layered zeolites using different phosphine oxides, including trimethylphosphine, triethylphosphine, tributylphosphine, and trioctylphosphine oxides.[234] The number and relative strengths of acid sites were evaluated based on the chemical shifts and areas of the peaks in the 31P NMR spectra after adsorption of the respective phosphine oxide. It was thus possible to differentiate acid sites located at the external surface and in the pores (internal) by choosing the phosphine oxides with appropriate sizes.[235]
Chemical shifts in the 31P NMR spectra of trimethylphosphine oxide were correlated with deprotonation energies of the respective acid sites in 2D zeolites.[236] The resulting dependence was linear and it allowed an assessment of Brønsted acid sites distribution by strengths.[237] Seo et al. evaluated the acid strength and concentration of Brønsted acid sites on the external surface of 2D MFI zeolite using trimethylphosphine oxide and tributylphosphine oxide as probe molecules.[233] Analysis of the 31P NMR spectra revealed three types of Brønsted acid sites located on the external surface of zeolite nanosheets, characterized by different strengths, while four different internal sites were detected.[237] Using decalin cracking as a test reaction, the concentration of the strongest acid sites at the surface was correlated with the catalytic activity. A linear dependence of cracking activity on the number of acid centers was found.
The Brønsted acidity of 3D and 2D MFI zeolites was recently investigated computationally, using DFT methods, periodic models, and molecular dynamics.[234c] Acidity was probed by trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site in the vicinity of framework Al atom at the T2 position located on both the internal and external surfaces. Based on calculated 31P NMR of TMPO/H-MFI adsorption complexes, three types of 31P chemical shifts were described: i) very strong acidity, observed when a proton is transferred from Brønsted site to TMPO, ii) strong acidity, observed when a proton is shared between framework oxygen and TMPO, and iii) weak acidity, observed when a proton is shared by more TMPO molecules. Moreover, the computational study of HernandezTamargo showed that chemical shifts depend on the number of TMPO probe molecules in the vicinity of the acid site.[234c] It follows that the interpretation of experimental NMR data is more complicated and a good overlap between state-of-the art computational and experimental investigations is necessary.

sections.heading: 3.2. Design of 2D Zeolites
sections.text: Synthesis of 2D zeolites can be performed either via bottom-up or top-down approaches. Bottom-up approaches include hydrothermal synthesis (leading usually to conventional 3D zeolites) with specifically adjusted reaction conditions or synthesis with appropriate structure-directing agents. The top-down approach relies on the careful disassembly of already prepared zeolites. The 2D zeolites can be subsequently: i) exfoliated and used as catalysts, membranes, etc., or ii) used as extended building units for the preparation of pillared materials with either organic or inorganic props or for the synthesis of new materials, including new zeolites. The efficient and complete exfoliation of as-made 2D zeolites (a main challenge nowadays) is discussed in Section 3.2.5.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Direct (Bottom-Up) Approaches
sections.text:
The most recognized 2D zeolites are the intermediate products (so called layered precursors) appearing during the conventional hydrothermal syntheses using simple structure-directing agents (SDAs). Thermally induced topotactic condensation of layered precursors results in the formation of conventional 3D
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (20 of 33)
zeolites. MCM-22P was the first layered precursor synthesized by direct hydrothermal route[238] and it is the most studied 2D zeolite. Due to the absence of covalent bonding between the layers (they are held together by dispersion interaction and interlayer hydrogen bonding; for analysis of interlayer interactions see, e.g., refs. [239,240]), MCM-22P can be relatively easily swollen, pillared, and delaminated.[241] Precursors of FER and CDO are the other directly synthesized 2D zeolites. Both are composed of nonporous ferrierite-type silicate layers constituting the structures of 3D FER and CDO zeolites. Some of RUB materials (RUB-20, RUB-36, RUB-38, RUB-40, and RUB-48) can also be related to FER/CDO precursors despite differing in the layer-to-layer arrangement and nature of SDA between zeolite nanosheets (tetramethylammonium, diethyldimethylammonium, methyltriethylammonium, tetramethylphosphonium, and trimethylisopropylammonium).[242] The arrangement and organization of 2D FER/CDO precursors (PREFER) was also investigated computationally at the molecular mechanics level.[243] The critical role of cetyltrimethylammonium cation (used as SDA) for organization of layers was clearly demonstrated. Other types of layered zeolite precursors obtained by direct synthesis were reported during last two decades as well.[244]
A sophisticated approach based on the spatial templating phenomena was developed for the synthesis of layered zeolites with MFI topology.[216,245] The idea behind it is in the use of multifunctional cationic SDAs having at least two parts, one directing the formation of zeolite phase and another preventing the crystallization in one direction. Such bifunctional SDAs contain quaternary ammonium groups (e.g., N+(CH3)2) responsible for the zeolitization and hydrophobic fragment (typically, long aliphatic chains, e.g., C22H45) preventing the formation of 3D crystals. Both hydrophilic and hydrophobic
parts of multifunctional SDA molecules can be tuned in order to adjust the structure of final lamellar material. SDA used for the preparation of such 2D zeolite stays located in pores after the synthesis, and the length of the hydrophobic aliphatic chain determines the distance between the layers. Variation in the number of quaternary ammonium groups connected by short aliphatic bridges allows for control of the thickness of the resultant layers. Finally, the change of the nature of the nitrogen atom surrounding (e.g., using aryl groups instead of alkyl) can be used for a tuning of the crystallization process, leading to designed mesostructured zeolite nanosheets or intergrown layer assemblies.[246] In addition to the design of appropriate SDA molecules, variation of the synthesis conditions can be used to change the arrangement of the layers. Multi- and singe-layer disordered assemblies of MFI nanosheets were prepared in this way by Na et al.[247]
MWW zeolite was also synthesized in a layered form using multifunctional SDAs. For that purpose, simple cationic methylammonium fragments were substituted by adamantylammonium or diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane groups. In the latter case, the synthesis was performed in combination with secondary template—hexamethyleneimine. MIT-1 zeolite composed of delaminated MWW nanosheets was synthesized in one step using an adamantylammonium-based bifunctional SDA (Figure 11).[248] In the case of direct synthesis of layered MWW using SDA with diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane as a cationic head group, hexamethyleneimine (organic SDA typically used for conventional synthesis of MWW-family materials) was required to enhance zeolite crystallization.[249] Resulting 2D zeolites, in particular MIT-1, possessed superior textural properties when compared with layered MWW (MCM-56) prepared using the traditional hydrothermal route without addition of multifunctional SDAs.[248]

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Top-Down Approach
sections.text:
The top-down approach is based on the chemically selective transformation of the 3D zeolite into its 2D form, exploiting the anisotropy in the crystal structure and anisotropy in structure instabilities in particular. To make the 3D-to-2D transformation feasible, respective layers in parent zeolite should stay intact during the whole procedure. Only in such a case, disassembly of the fully condensed zeolite can lead to the formation of respective layered derivative.[250] The most important requirement for top-down transformation is the location of labile units between the layers. Both of the conditions mentioned above can be achieved for germanosilicates; many of them are composed of silicon-enriched 2D layers interconnected by germanium-enriched props, such as double-four rings (D4Rs). High Si/Ge ratio in the layers ensures the stability of the 2D lamellas during the treatment, while low Si/Ge ratio in D4Rs provides required lability and facilitates decomposition or rearrangement of respective units. Gentle and chemically selective disassembly of germanosilicate zeolites with various topologies (e.g., UTL, ITH, IWR, and ITR[250]) is possible: Ge-rich D4Rs can be removed and resulting 2D materials have the structure of the layers in “parent” zeolites. In contrast to 2D materials prepared by the bottom-up approach, the top-down approach results in the formation of thin layers with thickness below one unit cell of a parent zeolite. This can be considered an advantage since the layers with a thickness of a few atoms are highly desirable. However, small thickness of the layers (in addition to the fact that some of produced lamellas are porous) leads to a poor stability of the respective 2D zeolitic layers. This can restrict their applicability for postsynthesis transformations such as swelling or exfoliation because of the severe conditions typically applied. One more feature limiting swelling and exfoliation of 2D zeolites obtained using the top-down method is high surface density of hydroxyl groups formed upon disassembly of layers. Strong hydrogen bond interactions keep layers together.[239,240,251]
Instead of the direct use as 2D materials, such layered derivatives can be used as “extended” building blocks for organization (arrangement of layers assemblies in some systematic way) followed by reassembly (topotactic condensation) of the layers to form 3D zeolites. It was found that such reassembly allows synthesis of new types of zeolites not yet obtained by direct hydrothermal approach.[252,253] The general strategy of this multistep transformation is known as assembly–disassembly–organization–reassembly (ADOR).[254] First applied to zeolite with UTL structure,[255] ADOR was recently expanded to other 3D germanosilicate zeolites, including UOV[256] and SAZ-1.[257] In addition, appropriate shifting of individual zeolitic layers followed by condensation can lead to the formation of novel zeolites with odd/ring channels.[258] Those zeolites are still very rare in contrast to the many proposed by theoretical calculations and their synthesis has been considered as “unfeasible.”[259]

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Methods Based on the Control of Crystal Growth
sections.text:
Methods based on the crystal growth control were developed for the synthesis of layered zeolite materials in the absence of
SDAs as porogens (organic molecules can still participate in the synthesis mechanism). Nontemplating methods can use the adjustment of the synthesis conditions or the control of crystal growth direction. Both the organic and inorganic morphology modifiers can tune the thickness of zeolite crystals. The mechanism involving morphology modifiers is related to their selective interaction with certain crystal facets resulting in the incommensurate growth rate in different directions. The main disadvantage of approaches based on the control of crystal growth is that layer thicknesses of less then several tens of nanometers are rarely achievable.
Different organosilanes (such as 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl hexadecyldimethyl ammonium or 3-(trimethoxysilyl) propyl octadecyldimethyl ammonium compounds) were used for the direct synthesis of FAU zeolite with a hierarchical architecture.[260,261] Thus, synthesized zeolite nanosheets form “houseof-cards-like” assemblies providing the pore system consisting of: i) meso/macropores between the nanosheet stacks, ii) intracrystalline mesopores, and iii) conventional zeolitic micropores (Figure 12). Complex organosilane molecules used to affect the crystal growth are difficult to prepare and the removal of the unreacted part is required by the postsynthetic treatment. However, simple inorganic salts can be used as morphology modifiers as well. The isomorphous substitution of different metals (Co, Ni, Zn, etc.) into the zeolite MFI framework using tetrahalometallates or ammonia complexes of respective metals leads to an increase in the crystal aspect ratio and to the reduction of crystal size while the increased twinning is considered as a side effect.[262] Inayat et al. used this method to modify the morphology of FAU crystals using zinc or lithium salts.[263] Addition of zinc resulted in the formation of a zeolite with layer-like morphology (Figure 12) similar to that of FAU prepared using organosilanes discussed above. The use of lithium allowed the investigators to produce skeleton-like arrangement of layers with pronounced hexagonal (111) plates.
Preparation of FAU zeolite nanosheet assemblies, similar to that obtained using organosilanes or inorganic salts, is possible even without utilization of any morphology modifiers. Using the border conditions between FAU and EMT crystallization, Ferdov reported the synthesis of intergrown nanolayers by means of zeolite nanoparticles recrystallization.[264] The FAU/ EMT crystallite branching appears due to this recrystallization and it is followed by the formation of submicron faceted crystals. The concentration of aluminum is an important factor because its high content accelerates the formation of aggregates of plate-like crystals of FAU/EMT. At a low Al concentration, the formation of desired nanoparticles was observed. After recrystallization of these FAU nanoparticles, intergrown nanolayers with a thickness of 20–60 nm and a length of up to 2 µm were produced (Figure 12). Similar to the methods utilizing inorganic morphology modifiers, such a synthetic approach is environmentally friendly and can be economically efficient.
One of the approaches leading to the construction of 2D zeolitic layers with highly developed mesoporosity is the direct synthesis of self-pillared zeolitic nanosheets with MFI topology.[198] Despite the organic agent (tetrabutylphosphonium) used in this work, its main role consisted in the initiation of repetitive branching via the 90° rotational intergrowths of the crystallites with MFI and MEL (structural

twin of MFI) structure at the branching points, leading to formation of assembly of zeolite nanosheets. Tetrabutylphosphonium appears to be an important contributor to the anisotropic growth of single unit cell layers because it induced the formation of MEL phase during the crystallization of a self-pillared material. The formation of secondary-type zeolite domains within the primary-type structure may lead to repetitive branching of nanosheets (twinning mechanism) and it can be generalized and used for other zeolite twins. For successful implementation, the zeolite should exist in the layered form (with a small thickness and a high aspect ratio) and it must allow the branching to occur at certain angles.[198]

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Support-Assisted Approaches
sections.text:
Graphene oxide is a thermally and mechanically stable layered material with the well-developed surface. Graphene oxide can thus be used as a building block for the preparation of hybrid nanocomposites and soft materials.[265] It can be used as a 2D facilitating agent for the synthesis of 2D zeolite–graphene oxide composites.[266] Graphene oxide nanosheets were added to the reaction mixture during the synthesis of multilamellar MFI. Zeolite layers were grown along both graphene oxide surfaces and compatible intergrowth of both types of nanosheets was observed. Assembly of b-oriented MFI nanosheets with reduced intergrowth of zeolite crystals possessing only moderate BET areas (about 650 m2 g−1) can be obtained after removal of organic SDA molecules and graphene oxide layers by calcination. Note that the deoxygenation of graphene oxide phase to the respective reduced form gives a material with relatively high electrical conductivity that is orders of magnitude higher that in the as-synthesized composite (423 and 0.19 S m−1, respectively). This indicates efficient reduction of graphene oxide located in
the intercrystalline space of zeolite assemblies. The possibility to adjust the conductivity by the change of zeolite/graphene oxide ratio enables the preparation of systems with a continuously tunable electrical conductivity.
2D silica and silicate films can be prepared on metal substrates, including Pd(100)[267] and Pd(111),[268] and Ru(0001)[269,270] and metal alloys.[271] While it is good approach to study 2D materials by combination of experimental and theoretical techniques, it is not a practical method for the preparation of 2D zeolites. This approach requires the deposition of a metal film on the support, the metal film cleaning, and then the deposition of silica/alumina source. If the deposited material does not strongly chemisorb to the metal, but rather weakly physisorbs, the layer grows incommensurately (e.g., the case of silica on Pd[267]). Doping with Al can cause the softening of the material, reducing lattice strain energy and formation of a commensurate phase due to the stronger interaction between the metal and the aluminosilicate layer. Stronger interaction in the latter case corresponds to the electrostatic interaction and partial charge transfer between negatively charged aluminosilicate layer and the metal substrate and results in PdO bond formation.[268] Systems prepared by deposition of silica on metal substrates do not have any silanol groups on their surface and they can be considered as perfect models for investigation of various properties using numerous surface science experimental characterizations. The Al atom in 2D layers prepared on Ru(0001) substrate preferentially locates in the vicinity of Ru and it is charged compensated by the metal (no Brønsted acid sites are formed); however, for Si/Al < 4 at least some Al atoms are located in the upper layer and BA sites are formed.[272] Properties of 2D aluminosilicate formed on Ru (denoted H-2dH) were investigated by a combination of experimental techniques and DFT calculations.[273] Results obtained for 2D H-2dH were compared with 3D zeolite CHA which has a similar topology.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Postsynthesis Modification of 2D Zeolites
sections.text:
The postsynthesis transformation of 2D zeolites can be defined as processes that alter the structure of nanosheet assemblies but not the intralayer zeolite structure. Well-recognized postsynthesis modification techniques include ionic exchange, intercalation (in particular, swelling), pillaring with amorphous or crystalline props, exfoliation, delamination, and interlayer expansion (silylation of zeolitic nanosheets forming interlayer-expanded zeolites).[274] The postsynthesis transformation of 2D zeolites with the MWW and MFI structure has been investigated the most. The first reported zeolite pillared with silica was MCM-36 (belongs to MWW family).[275] Pillared forms of zeolites can be prepared after the swelling of layers using an agent sufficient to break the interlayer interactions provided by hydrogen bonding and dispersion forces. To ease the swelling procedure it is usually performed at high pH[275] in the presence of a surfactant. Typical surfactant molecules possess small quaternary ammonium head groups and long aliphatic chains. After penetration of surfactant between the lamellas the interlayer space expands and the zeolite nanosheets become separated by several nanometers.[241] The addition of the source for the formation of interlayer props leads to pillaring with the interlayer distance defined by the particular surfactant. In the case of inorganic pillars, materials with desirable catalytic properties can be obtained, e.g., by addition of Ti or Sn sources together with silica.[276] In the case of organic props, multifunctional or hybrid materials can be designed.[277,278]
Independent and irregularly stacked layers of MWW zeolite (MCM-56 material) can be obtained directly by hydrothermal synthesis.[267] The absence of nanosheet intergrowth or other kinds of covalent bonding between the layers in MCM-56 was confirmed by its successful swelling.[279] MCM-56 zeolite is an exception because delamination of layered precursors is typically carried out via swelling, sonication, and acidification, i.e., under relatively harsh conditions.[280] Such severe treatment can lead to a partial recrystallization or amorphization of the delaminated zeolite. Therefore, the synthesis of suspensions containing discrete and nonaggregated zeolite nanosheets with intact crystalline structure is complicated. The structural deterioration and morphological damage (fragmentation, curling, and aggregation) of 2D zeolites during delamination or exfoliation may easily occur.[281]
Varoon et al. recently reported the complete exfoliation of MWW and MFI layers.[282] Exfoliated nanosheets with MWW topology were produced from swollen precursor ITQ-1, while multilamellar silicalite-1 used for the synthesis of exfoliated MFI layers did not require preliminary layer expansion. Nonaggregated zeolite nanosheets were produced by melt blending with polystyrene followed by its removal. Above the transition temperature of polystyrene, the extrusion process provided a shear force, which resulted in exfoliation of zeolite layers. If the thermal treatment of nanosheet–polymer nanocomposite was used for further removal of polymer component, the obtained layers suffered from significant curling. In contrast, dissolution of polystyrene in an appropriate solvent (toluene) allowed the investigators to obtain flat, exfoliated zeolite nanosheets. Thus, a simple dissolution of the polymer–zeolite nanocomposite
followed by a removal of unexfoliated nanosheet assemblies using centrifugation resulted in the preparation of morphologically intact nanosheets with MFI or MWW structures. Due to the completeness of the exfoliation procedure and morphological homogeneity, these nanosheets can be utilized for preparation of membranes by layers packing on porous supports during filtration. The following hydrothermal treatment allowed the preparation of zeolite membranes with thickness below 400 nm. These membranes possessed molecular sieving properties and allowed to separate p-xylene from o-xylene with a separation factor up to 70. The p-xylene permeability was reasonably high and reached 3 × 10−7 mol m−2 s−1 Pa−1 at 150 °C.
Exfoliation combined with efficient purification can lead to fabrication of even thinner zeolite membranes from 2D zeolites. Agrawal et al.[283] performed complete removal of unexfoliated particles after melt blending with polystyrene. They obtained MFI nanosheets with uniform thickness and lateral size with an aspect ratio of about 100. It was done using density gradient centrifugation based on the differences in sedimentation velocity of exfoliated and aggregated nanolayers in a fluid medium with density gradient along the depth of the fluid. Dispersion of respective nanosheets in aqueous medium can suffer from low stability due to a presence of long hydrophobic chains of multifunctional SDA on the surface of MFI layers. To optimize the separation conditions, different combinations of organic solvents were used to obtain complete dispersion of MFI nanosheets. n-Octanol was the best choice for dispersion of the layers and stabilization of the resulting suspension. Purification of exfoliated nanosheets was performed by centrifugation after insertion of nanosheets in n-octanol over density stacks created by chlorobenzene, dichloromethane, and chloroform (the sequence of solvents corresponds to increasing density). Four different fractions of zeolite particles were thus collected: 1) only exfoliated particles present, 2) containing two unexfoliated particles per 5000 nanosheets, 3) with large number of unexfoliated particles, and 4) primarily comprised of unexfoliated assemblies of MFI layers. Separated MFI nanosheets were used for fabrication of 80 nm thick films, which were further hydrothermally treated to form uniform membranes with a thickness of about 200 nm. Prepared membranes exhibited moderate molecular sieving properties (separation factor of p-xylene from o-xylene was in the range 25–45), while p-xylene permeability (4 × 10−7 mol m−2 s−1 Pa−1 at 150 °C) was improved in comparison with previous studies[282] and it was comparable to that of the alumina used as a support for membrane preparation. Improved membranes were recently prepared using exfoliated MFI nanosheets using the floating-particle coating method, which allowed for production of closely-packed nanosheet monolayers.[284] The density and uniformity of prepared films were higher in comparison with those obtained through Langmuir–Schaefer deposition and filtration methods. Nanosheet films deposited on porous silica supports by floating-particle coating were further modified by gel-free secondary growth to produce membranes and unprecedented ultraselective performance was demonstrated for separation of xylene isomers: p-xylene/o-xylene separation factor was higher than 10 000 at 150 °C (o-xylene signal was under the detection limit) and permeability up to 3 × 10−7 mol m−2 s−1 Pa−1 was achieved.

Exfoliation methods described above are in general timeconsuming, costly, and provide only a low-yield of nanosheets, which can be fragmented. Alternatively, high yield and low cost direct synthesis of nanolayers with high aspect ratio was proposed by Jeon et al.[213] A nanocrystal-seeded growth mechanism triggered by a single rotational intergrowth was used to synthesize MFI nanosheets with a thickness of 5 nm and lateral dimensions that were characteristic for conventional MFI crystals (up to 2.0 µm). Initial MFI nanoseeds were ≈30 nm in diameter and synthesis was carried out in the presence of relatively simple bis-tetraalkylammonium SDA, which can limit MFI crystal growth along the b-axis and direct the formation of plate-like MFI particles. The obtained high aspect ratio nanosheets were used as precursors for production of defect-free membranes with thickness below 1 µm by coating of porous substrates followed by gel-free secondary growth. As a result, initial zeolite layers with a thickness of 5 nm were intergrown to produce high-flux and ultraselective MFI membranes with excellent efficiency (p-xylene/o-xylene separation factor was 2500 at 125 °C). Separation performance of membranes supported by porous silica was better than that of membranes made by exfoliated nanosheets (except those prepared by floating-particle coating) or nanoparticles with MFI structure. After five weeks at temperatures cycled between 150 and 50 °C, the p-xylene/o-xylene separation factor only decreased by 40%, from 2000 to around 1200. During the same period, p-xylene permeability slightly changed from 5.6 × 10−7 to 3.5 × 10−7 mol m−2 s−1 Pa−1.
There are several modifications of melt-blending approach toward stable self-standing 2D zeolites, which can be found in the literature. Layered zeolite precursors (MWW and MFI) were successfully exfoliated by brief shearing or sonication with the assistance of commercially available telechelic liquid polybutadienes at room temperature (Figure 13).[285] The original procedure (using polystyrene) was considered as challenging due to the high operation temperature (>150 °C), low yield, and potential deterioration of 2D zeolites framework caused by a high energy input. Therefore, exfoliation of MCM-22(P) and multilamellar MFI was performed by their suspension in polybutadiene followed by brief shearing. Sonication is an effective procedure in exfoliating, but requires a longer time with respect to the flow treatment. The thickness of both types of nanosheets was consistent with that reported previously (2.5 nm for MWW and 3.4 for MFI zeolites, respectively). It was also found that
the end groups of polybutadienes play a crucial role in the exfoliation process. Nonfunctionalized polybutadiene and polymers possessing hydroxyl or carboxyl groups were also used for the exfoliation of 2D MWW. Nonfunctionalized polymers were completely ineffective in exfoliation, while hydroxyl-terminated polybutadiene was the most efficient.

sections.heading: 3.3. Catalysis by 2D Zeolites
sections.text: 2D zeolites were shown to be good catalysts for oxidation as well as acid-catalyzed reactions and they catalyze also reactions of bulky molecules that cannot enter the microporous systems of conventional 3D zeolites. The main benefits of 2D zeolites (as a subgroup of hierarchical materials) for catalysis include: i) high external surface areas (in the order of 400–700 m2 g−1) and interparticle volumes in comparison with those of 3D zeolites, ii) high accessibility of active centers of different nature (e.g., Al, Ti, Sn acid sites, or metal nanoparticles) on the external surface, and iii) the possibility to synthesize 2D zeolites with isolated, well-defined acid, base, and/or redox active sites in framework positions similar to 3D frameworks.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Acid-Catalyzed Reactions
sections.text:
Alkylation and Acylation Reactions: The superior performance of layered zeolites as catalysts for petrochemical processes (e.g., cracking, hydrocracking, alkylation of aromatics and paraffins) was first reported in patent literature in the early 1990s.[286] Alkylation of butane with isobutene was mainly investigated over MWW zeolite—the only topology known at that time in both 3D and 2D forms. MCM-36 (pillared MWW) was shown to possess higher activity and stability in paraffin alkylation in comparison with rare earth metal exchanged Y catalyst.[286] MCM-56 (unilamellar MWW form obtained in one step-synthesis) showed higher activity, stability, and selectivity to the monoalkylated product in benzene alkylation with ethylene or propylene compared to 3D MCM-22 catalysts with same (MWW) topology of the layers.[287] Note that the 3D MCM-22 catalysts (showing lower activity than 2D MCM-36 and MCM-56 analogs) were commercialized for selective production of monosubstituted ethyl- and isopropyl-benzenes formed in the appropriately sized surface pockets of MWW.[288,289] Increased
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1801712
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1801712 (25 of 33)
activity of MWW layered zeolites in the alkylation of aromatics was explained by a high number of surface pockets containing accessible acid centers. Yet another 2D zeolite consisting of MWW monolayers arranged into the “house-of-cards” architecture (MIT-1) showed 3 times higher activity in alkylation of benzene with benzyl alcohol compared to 3D MWW (MCM-22) and 2D MWW (MCM-56) counterparts, which correlated with decreasing external surface area (513, 219, and 121 m2 g−1 for MIT-1, MCM-56, and MCM-22, respectively) and concentration of surface acid sites determined by 31P MAS NMR using trimethylphosphine and tributylphosphine oxides (210, 130, and 60 µmol g−1 for MIT-1, MCM-56, and MCM-22, respectively).[291]
A comparative study of the catalytic performance of layered MWW zeolites ITQ-2 (Sext = 670 m2 g−1, cacid sites = 47 µmol g−1), MCM-56 (Sext = 210 m2 g−1, cacid sites = 123 µmol g−1), and UZM-8 (Sext = 310 m2 g−1, cacid sites = 151 µmol g−1) in isopropylation of benzene revealed the highest yield of cumene over UZM-8 material possessing the highest concentration of acid sites and moderately developed surface. It is clear that very tiny details of the synthesis procedures of layered MWW type materials are responsible for differences in catalytic performance. Thus, synthesis protocols offer a large space for further improvements in terms of external surface areas and accessible acid site concentrations. At the same time, all layered MWW zeolites outperformed their 3D counterpart (MCM-22) with respect to both conversion and selectivity.[219,290] The presence of mesoporosity between the lamellar MFI nanosheets is behind the observed increase of indole conversion compared to 3D MFI zeolite (from 4 to 97%) and selectivity to 3-acetylindole (from 30 to 75%) in the indole acylation reaction.[291]
Cracking: The performance of multi- and unilamellar MFI nanolayers and conventional 3D MFI zeolite in catalytic cracking of polyethylene was compared by Choi et al.[216] The increasing conversion of polyethylene in the sequence 3D MFI (27% after 30 min), multilamellar 2D MFI (45%), and unilamellar 2D MFI (85%) was explained by increasing BET surface area in multilamellar (420, 520, and 710 m2 g−1 for 3D, multilamellar, and unilamellar MFI, respectively). However, the role of mesopore size and distribution for the transformation of bulky polyethylene molecules cannot be excluded. A larger pore diameter in unilamellar (≈15 nm) then in multilamellar (≈3.5 nm) zeolite may also contribute to the superior activity of unilamellar MFI zeolite.
The benefits of highly accessible acid centers of delaminated 2D MWW zeolite (ITQ-2, Si/Al = 50) in cracking of n-decane, 1,3-diisopropylbenzene and vacuum gasoil were demonstrated with respect to 3D MWW (MCM-22, Si/Al = 50) zeolite by Corma et al.[280] Showing similar activity in the cracking of n-decane, ITQ-2 exhibited higher selectivity to valuable hydrocarbons than MCM-22. Higher selectivity of ITQ-2 was related to shorter diffusion paths for the high molecular weight substances (desired liquid products) in the delaminated zeolite. The reaction rate constant for cracking of bulkier 1,3-diisopropylbenzene was 1.5–2 times higher in ITQ-2 than in MCM-22; however, the selectivity toward valuable gasoline and diesel was lower in ITQ-2.
The increasing total concentration of acid sites in 3D MWW (62 µmol g−1) zeolite resulted in higher conversion of relatively small alkane (n-decane) compared to ITQ-2 zeolite
(44 µmol g−1), however, the performance of 3D MWW in gasoil cracking was worse.[292] Similarly, the activity of 3D FER zeolite (CBrønsted = 19 µmol g−1) in cracking of n-decane was shown to be comparable to that of 2D FER (ITQ-6, CBrønsted = 9 µmol g−1) containing a lower number of acid sites: rate constants k = 2.5 × 10−3 and 2.1 × 10−3 s−1 for 3D and 2D FER, respectively. However, ITQ-6 exhibits much higher activity in cracking of bulky 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene (k = 1.4 × 10−1 s−1) compared to 3D FER (k = 3.5 × 10−2 s−1) and this can be explained by the enhanced accessibility of acid sites in layered FER. While there are about 90% of acid sites at the external surface of ITQ-6, less than 5% of acid sites are on external surface of 3D zeolite, as shown by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed probe molecules.[293]
Methanol to Hydrocarbons: An unprecedented stability of MFI nanosheets in industrially important methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) process was reported by Choi et al.[216]: while the significant drop in methanol conversion was observed already in 4 d for 3D MFI, the extended lifetime of 15 d was found for the nanosheets (Figure 14). Such alteration in the stability of the catalysts was explained by the differences in the coke formation. Micropores of 3D MFI became blocked already at low coking levels, while coke deposited on the external surface of 2D MFI did not substantially obstruct diffusion of reagents. A higher activity of 2D versus 3D MFI in MTH process was also demonstrated by Zhu et al. (TON = 7.5 × 103 to 1 × 104 and 3 × 103 for 2D and 3D MFI, respectively).[294] In addition, 2D MFI showed a 2–7 time higher propylene-to-ethylene ratio in the products (C3= /C2= = 3.7–13.9 and 1.8 for 2D and 3D MFI, respectively) at comparable yields and composition of C4 and C5+ fractions. Thus, appropriate selectivity as well as high activity and stability indicates that 2D zeolites are promising catalysts for MTH processes.
Condensation reactions: The large external surfaces of lamellar zeolites are particularly advantageous for condensation reactions involving bulky reagents. Despite containing less Al, both multilamellar (48% conversion) and unilamellar (76%) MFI zeolites were more active in comparison with 3D MFI (16%) in Claisen–Schmidt condensation.[216] Facile cyclization on the surface of lamellar zeolites also resulted in improved selectivity for flavanone (62–64%) compared to 3D (50%) MFI. The layered MFI zeolite with 1.5 nm thick nanosheets showed a higher activity in aldol condensation of benzaldehyde and heptanal compared either to 3D MFI or mesoporous Al-MCM-41 catalysts (85, 9, and <5% conversion, respectively).[295] These results were related to a higher concentration of surface acid sites accessible for bulky reagents in 2D versus 3D zeolites and to the higher strength of acid sites in 2D MFI than in Al-MCM-41.[296,297]
The beneficial catalytic performance of the MFI nanosheets compared to 3D MFI and Al-MCM-41 was also observed for the condensation reaction yielding vitamin E.[291] While negligible yields of products were achieved with 3D MFI and Al-MCM-41 (1–4%), the MFI nanosheets possessing sufficiently strong acid centers accessible to reactants showed 75–89% conversion with reasonable selectivity to vitamin E (74–86%).
The catalytic activity of 2D MFI zeolites in annulation of phenols with methylbutenol was compared with that of conventional catalysts having micrometer-sized crystals—commercial medium-pore MFI, large-pore BEA, and ultrastable

micro–mesoporous FAU zeolite (USY). A set of 2D catalysts under investigation included mesostructured MFI nanolayers with the same chemical composition, micropore sizes, and the narrow mesopore size distribution. Layered zeolites differed only in the thickness of crystalline sheets. The yield of targeted chromane increased with a micropore diameter of 3D zeolite (MFI < BEA < USY) and with the decreasing thickness of crystalline layers in 2D MFI. While investigated 2D zeolites had lower concentration of acid sites than 3D ones, 2D zeolites showed a higher activity. This result was related to the welldeveloped mesopore structure and large external surface area of layered zeolites which facilitates diffusion of reactants and products. The advantageous catalytic behavior of 2D catalysts over bulk zeolites became more prominent when using bulkier 2-naphthol as a substrate. The layered catalysts surpass not only medium-pore MFI and large-pore zeolite BEA, but also micro– mesoporous USY zeolite, which was explained by an optimal size of mesopores within 2D catalysts that is sufficient for the activation of the substrate and for the formation of bulky intermediates.[298]
Catalytic activity of BA sites located on internal and external surfaces of H-ZSM-5 was investigated computationally for the Beckmann rearrangement reaction.[299] We can compare the results obtained for external and internal surfaces to get insight into the differences in catalytic activities of 3D and 2D H-ZSM-5. For smaller reactants (acetoxime), the reaction preferentially proceeds on internal surface BA sites at both 300 and 598 K. On the contrary, for larger reactants (cyclohexanone oxime) the reaction proceeds exclusively on the internal surface BA site at 300 K while the BA site on the external surface dominated the reaction at 598 K.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Red-Ox Reactions
sections.text:
Ti- and Sn-containing 2D zeolites were shown to be sustainable catalysts for Red-Ox reactions, e.g., epoxidation of
olefins,[300] Baeyer–Villiger reaction,[301] oxidation of benzene with nitrous oxide,[302] hydroxylation of phenol,[303] and Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction.[304] In most cases, layered zeolites exhibited improved catalytic activities in transformation of bulky molecules compared to ordered mesoporous materials and conventional 3D zeolites.[305] Layered Ti-substituted MEL zeolite showed a higher activity in comparison to 3D Ti-MEL in the oxidation of phenol (TOF = 25.2 and 15.6 h−1 for 2D and 3D MEL, respectively) and epoxidation of cyclohexene with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TOF = 37.7 and 19.3 h−1 for 2D and 3D MEL, respectively).[303] Similarly, Ti-ITQ-6 showed higher activity in the oxidation of hexene with hydrogen peroxide than the 3D Ti-FER counterpart (TON = 23 and 6 for Ti-ITQ-6 and Ti-FER, respectively).[306] Self-pillared Sn-containing 2D MFI zeolite showed a remarkably higher yield of fructose (65%) in glucose isomerization than 3D Sn-BEA zeolite and Sn-MCM-41 mesoporous molecular sieve (<32%). The result was related to the higher accessibility of acid sites in the pillared 2D zeolite. Verheyen et al.[306] considered the transition state selectivity in 2D MFI zeolite based on the absence of ethyl- and propylbranched isomers among the products of n-decane isomerization. Slightly lower yields of 2,7-dimethyloctane found over 2D MFI (13–16% and 20% for 2D and 3D MFI, respectively) were explained by sensitivity of the shape selectivity effect on the diffusion path, which was lower in 2D MFI.
Functionalization of 2D zeolites with metal nanoparticles enlarged a set of reactions efficiently catalyzed by layered zeolites. Catalytic performance of 2D MFI functionalized with Pt nanoparticles was compared to that of Pt-containing 3D MFI and BEA zeolites in n-heptane hydroisomerization.[300] Negligible differences in conversion values in n-heptane transformation observed for 2D and 3D zeolites revealed that the reaction was not diffusion controlled. However, selectivity to i-C7 increased continuously from 26.2% to 58.7% with the decreasing thickness of MFI nanolayers from 300 to 2 nm and was explained by suppression of consecutive cracking of branched C7 isomers. Complementary results have been

obtained by Zhu et al., who also observed significantly higher selectivity of Pt-modified MFI nanosheets in comparison to bulk MFI zeolite (90–95 vs 56% for 2D and 3D MFI, respectively) at comparable conversion of n-heptane in hydroisomerization reaction.[294]
Martinez and Prieto found that better dispersion of Co nanoparticles reached during functionalization of ITQ-2 layers (the size of Co nanoparticles was in the range 5–11 nm) resulted in a significantly higher yield for Co supported on ITQ-2 versus Co/silica gel in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (14–53 × 10−3 vs 3.3 × 10−3 molCO gCo−1 h−1 for Co/ITQ-2 and Co/silica gel, respectively).[307] Both Co/ITQ-2 and Co/ITQ-6, characterized by excellent reducibility of Co nanoparticles, showed higher selectivity to C5+ products compared to Co/Silica gel and Co/MCM-41 (72–78% for ITQ materials vs 45–65% of C5+ selectivity for noncrystalline silica materials). A 70% increase in activity of Co/ITQ-6 was explained by the smaller average size of Co nanoparticles in ITQ-6 (9.3 nm) vs ITQ-2 (11.7 nm).[308] However, both activity and selectivity obtained for Co-supported 2D zeolites in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis were lower than the values reported in the literature for other Cosupported catalysts.[309]
Martinez et al. compared Mo-modified layered ITQ-2 and 3D MWW catalysts in methane dehydroaromatization.[310] Both catalysts yielded ethane/ethylene, benzene, toluene, and naphthalene as the main products. Mo/ITQ-2 showed lower selectivity to monocyclic aromatics than Mo/MWW (62% vs 65% selectivity to benzene), which was the lowest shape selectivity in layered zeolites. A careful dealumination of the external surface of ITQ-2 with oxalic acid led to an increase of benzene selectivity from 62 to 75% on the expense of naphthalene (selectivity decreased from 28 to 14%).
Wu et al.[311] designed hierarchical micro–mesoporous Momodified lamellar MFI zeolites with remarkable selectivity for methane dehydroaromatization; a 95% selectivity to monocyclic aromatic was observed for 2D Mo/MFI with the optimized ratio of micro- and mesopores. However, overcoming the current conversion limitation of the discussed Mo-supported 2D zeolites (below 5%) remains a challenge.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
2D oxide nanomaterials constitute a broad range of systems, with a wide array of current and potential applications, particularly in the field of renewable energy. It is important to further explore the peculiar properties of 2D oxides since they have been shown to exhibit superior performance in a number of applications. However, the industrial use of 2D oxides is currently very limited. A major challenge remains the transformation of 2D oxides into stable 3D hierarchical materials that can be upscaled and used industrially.
It is important to also remark that other types of oxide nanostructures relevant for catalysis (including for example, photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, and thus to design improved electrodes[38]) are present in literature, for example nanowires, branched nanostructured films, and networks of nanoparticles. By controlling the nanostructure it is possible to obtain properties different from those of small 3D-type nanoparticles.[38,64a,c]
This is the common aspect joining the materials discussed here (2D/layered oxides) and these other types of nanostructures although present knowledge still does not allow for the prediction of when and why a specific nanostructure could be preferable.
Despite the many similarities in structure, composition, synthetic methods, and uses, the current literature on layered oxides is diverse and disconnected. In this review, we summarize the recent developments in all important 2D oxide systems: i) supported ultrathin oxide films, ii) layered clays, iii) double hydroxides, iv) layered perovskites, and v) 2D zeolites. Each of the five types of layered oxides discussed herein is traditionally viewed as individual research fields. Particular attention is paid here to the underlying similarities and differences between the various materials, and the subsequent challenges faced by each research field. As remarked in Section 1.4 and through the text, there is, however, an important difference between 2D-type zeolites on one side and the other 2D/layered oxides discussed on the other side. This is related to the different degree of flexibility, and aspects such as nonstoichiometry, surface relaxation, phonons and lattice dynamics, and charge distribution among other features. Combining these two broad classes of materials provides a possibility to better understand when and why these different characteristics could be exploited. The present lack of a clear scientific rationale across the literature on how to exploit such characteristics represents the challenge for a knowledgebased design of novel catalytic materials.
There are many areas in which a common view could open new possibilities. For example, one of the major recent advances in zeolites is the possibility to manipulate 2D zeolites, organize them, and even synthetize new 3D zeolites. It has been shown that 2D zeolites can be viewed as building blocks to be used in the preparation of various 3D materials, e.g., hybrid inorganic–organic structures, where 2D zeolites are held together via organic linkers. Translating these concepts to other types of layered oxides, i.e., developing ways to manipulate 2D building blocks to create new materials or nanoarchitectures to improve performance, is one of the most exciting concepts to be developed.[16]
For catalytic applications, several of the discussed materials offer somewhat unique possibilities to develop multifunctional catalysts that allow for one-pot, complex multistage reactions. This has been clearly demonstrated for layered clays and hydrotalcites. On the contrary, the development of truly multifunctional catalysts is at a very early stage in the case of 2D zeolites. It follows from such examples that it is important and potentially beneficial to overlap the knowledge in individual 2D oxides fields and that it will lead to new potential applications. Specific attention is also devoted to the bridge between experimental and theoretical investigation of 2D oxides. This cooperation has often led to deeper insight and understanding of the physical origin of chemical properties in layered oxides.
The potential of layered oxides toward future applications is critically evaluated, especially in the areas of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, biomass conversion, and fine chemical synthesis. The corresponding novel 3D materials, either inorganic or hybrid inorganic/organic, which can be obtained via sophisticated engineering of 2D oxides, are also explored. Furthermore, the question is how to use nanostructure characteristics and layer-specific properties to create and maximize this catalytic nanoarchitecture in addition to the other properties necessary for catalytic behavior, such as stability to cycling, transport properties, and selectivity. While great progress has been made on these aspects, a gap still exists between model catalysts, where these aspects are better understood, and practical catalysts. Understanding between the differences between bulk- and 2D-type materials could thus be a way toward bridging this gap in catalysis by oxides.[312]
It should be again finally remarked that the application of these novel layered oxides is currently more phenomenological than design-based oxides, and that the advanced knowledge available today in the tailored synthesis of materials is still not yet fully exploited in terms of catalyst design. Such knowledgebased design of 2D-type materials for catalytic applications is certainly the interesting challenge for the near future.

metadata.abstractText: The ongoing energy transition to a more sustainable and lowcarbon future[1–3] pushes the development of advanced materials for energy and catalysis.[4–12] 2D or layered materials are interesting in this regard for their peculiar transient properties 2D oxide nanomaterials constitute a broad range of materials, with a wide array of current and potential applications, particularly in the fields of energy storage and catalysis for sustainable energy production. Despite the many similarities in structure, composition, and synthetic methods and uses, the current literature on layered oxides is diverse and disconnected. A number of reviews can be found in the literature, but they are mostly focused on one of the particular subclasses of 2D oxides. This review attempts to bridge the knowledge gap between individual layered oxide types by summarizing recent developments in all important 2D oxide systems including supported ultrathin oxide films, layered clays and double hydroxides, layered perov­ skites, and novel 2D­zeolite­based materials. Particular attention is paid to the underlying similarities and differences between the various materials, and the subsequent challenges faced by each research community. The potential of layered oxides toward future applications is critically evaluated, especially in the areas of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, biomass conversion, and fine chemical synthesis.
